text: We investigate the reliability of the assumption on the direction of the incident neutrino for two types of events in the Super-Kamiokande detector: fully contained events and partially contained events due to quasi-elastic scattering (QEL). By analyzing neutrino events occurring inside the detector, we examine the four possible L/E analyses: L_nu/E_nu, L_nu/E_mu, L_mu/E_nu, and L_mu/E_mu. The results show that only the L_nu/E_nu analysis can clearly exhibit the signature of maximum oscillations, while the L_mu/E_mu analysis, which is currently performed by the Super-Kamiokande Collaboration, fails to capture the maximum oscillation. Therefore, we suggest that the zenith angle distribution of neutrino events inside the detector be re-analyzed in order to identify the maximum oscillation. This study implies that the Super-Kamiokande type experiment, relying on L/E analysis, cannot effectively detect the maximum oscillation. By addressing this limitation, our findings provide valuable insights for improving the analysis techniques in neutrino experiments.
label: llm

text: Here is an 8 sentence abstract for the title "Monitoring Air Moisture with Laser Absorption Spectroscopy":Laser absorption spectroscopy is a technique that can be used for monitoring air moisture levels. A laser beam is passed through the air and its absorption of specific wavelengths is measured. Different molecules absorb different wavelengths allowing for precise identification. Water vapor strongly absorbs infrared wavelengths which provides an effective way to quantify moisture content. We developed an instrument that uses a tunable infrared laser and detector to continuously measure the absorption spectrum of air along a fixed path. The absorption spectra are analyzed to determine the concentration of water vapor along the beam path. Initial tests of the instrument show it can accurately determine moisture levels down to very small concentrations with high temporal resolution. This laser-based method provides an effective new tool for continuous and sensitive monitoring of air moisture content.

text: We present a phenomenological theory that describes the spin excitations in La- and Y-based cuprate superconductors. These materials have been extensively studied due to their high-temperature superconducting properties and the existence of a spin resonance peak in their excitation spectra. Our theory is based on the concept of magnons, collective spin excitations, and takes into account the coupling between the spin degrees of freedom and the charge carriers in the system.Using this framework, we analyze the temperature and doping dependence of the spin excitation spectrum in La- and Y-based cuprates. We find that the resonance peak is intimately related to the presence of superconductivity and is strongly influenced by the doping level. At optimal doping, the resonance peak reaches its maximum intensity and energy, indicating a close connection between spin excitations and the superconducting state.Furthermore, our theory predicts the existence of a spin gap in the excitation spectrum at low temperatures and underdoped regimes. This spin gap is associated with the formation of a pseudogap in the electronic density of states and reflects the presence of spin correlations that compete with superconductivity.We compare our theoretical predictions with experimental data obtained from neutron scattering measurements and find good agreement, supporting the validity of our approach. Our results provide valuable insights into the nature of spin excitations in La- and Y-based cuprates and contribute to the understanding of the underlying mechanisms of high-temperature superconductivity in these materials.In conclusion, our phenomenological theory offers a comprehensive description of the spin excitations in La- and Y-based cuprate superconductors. It successfully explains the temperature and doping dependence of the excitation spectra, as well as the emergence of the spin resonance peak and spin gap.

text: [assistant]: Brownian motion, a phenomenon characterized by the erratic movement of particles suspended in a fluid, has captivated the scientific community for centuries. text: The 3He(\(\alpha\),\(\gamma\))7Be reaction is a critical step in solar hydrogen fusion via the pp chain, but direct measurement of its astrophysical S-factor at the Gamow energy (E_c.m.= 1.56 MeV) is difficult.  In the present work, the S-factor was extracted using a Trojan Horse method with the 6Li(d, alpha)4He reaction at the center-of-mass energy of 2.45 MeV. The two low-lying states in 7Be were well separated in the excitation energy spectra measured in coincidence with prompt and delayed \(\gamma\)-rays. We achieved a systematic uncertainty below 5% and an uncertainty in the normalization factor of 3.2%. The extrapolated S-factor at E_c.m. = 1.56 MeV is (1.82 \(\pm\) 0.13) \(\times\) 10-15 MeV-b. The uncertainty of the present result is sufficiently small for the determination of the reaction rate.

text: Proper motion measurements provide valuable insights into the dynamics and formation history of stellar populations within the Milky Way. In this study, we present observations and model comparisons of red clump giants in the Galactic bulge to investigate their proper motion dispersions. We have obtained high-precision proper motions for a large sample of red clump stars in the bulge region using multi-epoch astrometric data from a combination of ground-based surveys. By analyzing the proper motion distributions, we aim to constrain the kinematic properties of the bulge and compare them with theoretical predictions. Our observations reveal significant variations in the proper motion dispersions across different line-of-sight directions within the bulge. These variations suggest the presence of complex motion patterns and possibly multiple stellar populations in the bulge region. We compare our measurements with state-of-the-art dynamical models tailored for the Milky Way bulge and find that some models can reproduce the observed proper motion dispersions reasonably well, while others show significant deviations. Our findings highlight the challenges in accurately modeling the kinematics of the Galactic bulge and the importance of adopting realistic dynamical models to understand its formation and evolution. Further investigations with more detailed simulations and improved data are necessary to refine our understanding of the dynamics and stellar populations within the bulge and their implications for galaxy formation theories.
label: llm

text: Here is a 6 sentence abstract for the given academic article title:We study a system of infinitely many bosons in the Cuntz algebra ${\cal O}_{\infty}$. Using the Cuntz algebra relations, we define creation and annihilation operators that add or remove a single boson from the system. We show that these operators generate an effective recursive dynamics where adding a boson induces creation on all previously existing bosons. We derive analytical expressions for the action of these recursive creation operators on bosonic Fock space. We also analyze the thermodynamic limit of this recursive boson system as the number of bosons becomes infinitely large. Finally, we discuss possible applications of this recursive boson model to problems in quantum field theory and many-body physics.

text: This paper presents an experimental test of non-local realism, which is the idea that physical objects can be instantaneously influenced by events happening far away. The test is based on the violation of a Bell inequality, which is a statistical inequality that is satisfied by all local realistic theories but can be violated by non-local theories. The experiment uses entangled photon pairs, where the polarization of one photon is correlated with the path of the other photon. The correlations between these measurements are analyzed, and the results show a violation of the Bell inequality by more than 24 standard deviations. This experimentally supports the idea that non-local realism is a fundamental concept that is not limited to specific physical realizations. The results also have implications for the development of quantum mechanics and the understanding of the nature of reality.
label: llm

text: Sure, here is an academic abstract based on the given title:The loop-quantum-gravity vertex-amplitude introduces a vertex amplitude for four-dimensional loop quantum gravity, derived from a conventional quantization of Regge discretization of Euclidean general relativity. This yields a spinfoam sum that corrects some difficulties of the Barrett-Crane theory, imposing the second-class simplicity constraints weakly, rather than strongly. The boundary states match those of SO(3) loop quantum gravity, providing a solution to the problem of connecting the covariant SO(4) spinfoam formalism with the canonical SO(3) spin-network formalism. The vertex amplitude is both SO(3) and SO(4)-covariant, rectifying the triviality of the Barrett-Crane vertex's intertwiner dependence, responsible for its failure to yield the correct propagator tensorial structure.

text: Here is an 8 sentence abstract for the given academic article title:The toric code is a topological quantum error correcting code that is robust against local perturbations. However, the topological properties of the toric code are only defined at zero temperature. In this paper, we study the effects of finite temperature on the entanglement and topological entropy of the toric code. We derive an analytic expression for the von Neumann entropy of a bipartition of the system at finite temperature. Our calculations show that the topological entropy decreases with increasing temperature but remains quantized even for temperatures comparable to the energy gap. We also investigate the thermal state of the toric code using tensor network simulations. The simulations allow us to calculate the topological entropy for larger system sizes. The results confirm that nonzero temperature destroys the long range topological order yet the topological entropy remains quantifiable in an intermediate temperature regime. Overall, our work characterizes the interplay between entanglement, topology and temperature in the toric code.
label: llm

text: In this paper, we present a novel approach to modelling the polarimetric variability of hot star winds. Our method takes into account the clumping of the wind material, which is known to affect the polarization signal. Our model is able to reproduce the observed variability in the polarization signal, and provides valuable insights into the physical processes that govern the winds of hot stars. We apply our method to several case studies, including the winds of Wolf-Rayet stars and OB stars. Our results show that clumping plays a crucial role in shaping the polarization properties of hot star winds, and that our model can accurately predict the observed variability. This work has important implications for the study of hot star winds and their role in the formation of stars and planetary systems.

text: We investigate the spin solid phases of spin 1 and spin 3/2 antiferromagnets on a cubic lattice. Using a combination of numerical simulations and analytical techniques, we explore the ground state properties of these systems. We find that both spin 1 and spin 3/2 antiferromagnets exhibit rich phase diagrams with various spin solid phases. The spin solid phases are characterized by the formation of magnetic order with a fixed number of spins per unit cell.In the case of spin 1 antiferromagnets, we identify several distinct spin solid phases, including the Néel phase, the collinear stripe phase, and the noncollinear spin solid phase. These phases arise from the competition between the exchange interactions and the single-ion anisotropy. Furthermore, we uncover the presence of quantum fluctuations in the spin solid phases, which give rise to interesting quantum magnetic phenomena.For spin 3/2 antiferromagnets, we find that the spin solid phases are more complex due to the larger spin size. In addition to the Néel phase and the collinear stripe phase, we observe the emergence of exotic spin solid phases such as the quadrupolar ordered phase and the biquadratic ordered phase. These phases result from the interplay between the exchange interactions and the higher-order spin interactions.Our findings shed light on the diverse spin solid phases that can arise in spin 1 and spin 3/2 antiferromagnets on a cubic lattice. The presence of quantum fluctuations and the emergence of exotic spin solid phases highlight the rich physics in these systems. Our results provide a basis for further theoretical and experimental investigations of spin solid phases in higher spin systems on different lattice geometries.

text: The slave-boson and doped-carrier theories are two complementary approaches to describe the electromagnetic response of high-Tc superconductors. In this paper, we compare the two theories and show that they give very similar results for the optical conductivity and the microwave conductivity. We also discuss the implications of the two theories for the interpretation of experiments.The slave-boson theory describes the high-Tc superconductors as a system of strongly correlated electrons. The electrons are divided into two groups: the slave bosons, which are responsible for the superconductivity, and the doped carriers, which are responsible for the normal conductivity.The doped-carrier theory describes the high-Tc superconductors as a system of weakly correlated electrons. The electrons are all treated on an equal footing, and there is no distinction between the slave bosons and the doped carriers.Both the slave-boson and doped-carrier theories give very similar results for the optical conductivity and the microwave conductivity. This is because the two theories are equivalent in the long-wavelength limit.However, the two theories have different implications for the interpretation of experiments. The slave-boson theory suggests that the high-Tc superconductors are a system of strongly correlated electrons, while the doped-carrier theory suggests that the high-Tc superconductors are a system of weakly correlated electrons.
label: llm

text: The spin-flip phenomenon in supermassive black hole binary mergers is a phenomenon in which the spin of the dominant black hole is reoriented during the merger process. This phenomenon occurs when the binary black holes have a mass ratio of 1:3 to 1:30, and the initially dominant orbital angular momentum becomes smaller than the spin during the inspiral phase of the merger. The spin-flip phenomenon can be observed in X-shaped radio galaxies, where the jets are reoriented. Based on galaxy luminosity statistics, it is argued that typical galaxy encounters involve mass ratios between 1:3 to 1:30 for central black holes. The spin-flip phenomenon can be described by post-Newtonian techniques and is expected to occur in the inspiral phase of the merger. This phenomenon provides insights into the formation and evolution of supermassive black holes in galaxies.

text: In this paper, we investigate the ability of phylogenetic mixtures on a single tree to mimic the tree topology of another tree. We show that such mixtures can indeed mimic the site pattern frequency vector of a resolved quartet tree, and we provide a simple criterion for determining when this is possible. Using geometric and combinatorial methods, we also study the structure of phylogenetic mixture distributions and show that the set of mixture distributions forms a convex polytope. We calculate the dimension of this polytope and use it to clarify the frequency of non-identifiable mixtures under the CFN model. Finally, we present a new combinatorial result that extends any identifiability result for a specific pair of trees of size six to arbitrary pairs of trees.

text: We investigate the formation processes of globular cluster systems (GCSs) in massive elliptical galaxies through a comprehensive analysis of the radial variation of stellar populations. Utilizing deep photometric data obtained from the Hubble Space Telescope, we examine the color distribution of the GCSs in a sample of five massive ellipticals. Our findings reveal significant multimodality in the GCSs, manifested by distinct color peaks observed at various radial distances. By comparing the GCS colors with stellar population synthesis models, we infer that the multiple peaks arise from the presence of different age and metallicity subpopulations within the GCSs. Our results support the scenario of a two-phase formation process for GCSs, involving an initial rapid formation phase followed by an extended period of slower assembly. Furthermore, we find a radial dependence in the relative contributions of different GCS subpopulations, with younger and more metal-rich clusters dominating in the central regions, while older and more metal-poor clusters become more prevalent in the outskirts. These radial variations provide valuable insights into the assembly history of massive ellipticals and suggest the importance of both in-situ and accretion-driven formation mechanisms in shaping GCS properties. Overall, our study highlights the significance of radial profiling of GCSs in understanding the complex interplay between stellar populations and galaxy formation processes in massive ellipticals.

text: We present the Millennium Galaxy Catalogue, a comprehensive compilation of galaxy data that includes measurements of B-band attenuation for both bulge and disc components. Our results show that the B-band attenuation of bulge light is significantly higher than that of disc light, indicating that bulges are more heavily obscured by dust. We find that the dust content of galaxies increases with increasing galaxy mass, and that the most massive galaxies have the highest dust-to-stellar mass ratios. Using our data, we estimate the cosmic dust density and find that it is consistent with previous studies. We also compute the stellar mass density of the universe and compare it to previous estimates, finding good agreement. Our results provide new insights into the properties of galaxy bulges and discs, and highlight the importance of considering dust attenuation when studying galaxy evolution.

text: In this study, we investigate the spin dynamics in underdoped YBa2Cu3O6.35 using neutron scattering. The spin susceptibility at high temperatures illustrates that the dominant energy scale is set by the temperature. At low temperatures, the scale length is geometric and not linked to dynamic widths. text: Here is a 13 sentence abstract for the given article title:Motivated by recent progress in reverberation mapping studies of active galactic nuclei (AGNs), we examine common methods used to estimate the size of broad line regions (BLRs) from lag measurements. While cross-correlation techniques have been widely applied, these traditional approaches have limitations when comparing unevenly sampled light curves with significant gaps. We explore an alternative approach that models the light curves directly using stochastic processes to recover time lags and associated uncertainties. We apply this method to archival monitoring data for 87 emission lines in 31 quasars. Preliminary results confirm past size-luminosity relationships, with some notable exceptions that motivate further investigation. The new approach can also simultaneously fit multiple lines and continua, improving lag estimates and providing correlation measurements between individual line lags. This additional information on lag correlations is critical for interpreting velocity-resolved reverberation results and line-response functions. With modifications to include luminosity-dependent lags or line responses, we demonstrate detection of scaling between BLR size and continuum luminosity in the variable AGN NGC 5548. Overall, the direct modeling technique shows promise for advancing reverberation mapping and our understanding of BLR structure and kinematics.

text: Abstract:In this study, we present the results of multidimensional supernova simulations that incorporate approximative neutrino transport, with a focus on the role of convection and the advective-acoustic cycle in the supernova core. text: The Magnetorotational Collapse of Population III StarsAbstract:We investigate the magnetorotational collapse of population III stars, which are the earliest stars to form in the universe. text: **Abstract**We develop a general model to calculate X-ray emissions from the accretion flows threaded by a large-scale dipole magnetic field, considering two-temperature plasmas for ions and electrons. This model is applied to the two accreting neutron star systems, Aql X-1 and 4U 1636-53. We find that the model can well explain the observed X-ray spectra and the broad-band spectral energy distributions of these two sources. Our calculations show that the anisotropic electron heating, and the magnetic field strength at the stellar surface play an important role in shaping the emergent X-ray spectra. The high energy cutoff of the power-law component in the X-ray spectrum could be an indication of the magnetic field strength at the stellar surface. The ratio between the electron and proton temperatures is found to be a crucial factor in determining the spectral shape in the soft X-ray band.

text: Abstract:In this study, we present a comprehensive calculation of prompt diphoton production cross sections at the energies of the Tevatron and the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). Prompt diphoton processes play a crucial role in probing the fundamental interactions of the Standard Model and beyond. Utilizing a threshold resummation formalism, we incorporate next-to-next-to-next-to-leading order (NNNLO) soft plus virtual QCD corrections at next-to-leading logarithmic (NLL) accuracy. Our analysis employs specific experimental constraints and theoretical inputs to determine the production rates and their uncertainties. We investigate the impact of bottom-quark Yukawa coupling on the diphoton cross sections, providing insights into the interactions involving the Higgs boson. Our findings not only contribute to the advancement of precision calculations but also aid in the evaluation of background rejection techniques in high-energy gamma-ray astronomy experiments. We demonstrate that this property is equivalent to Kolmogorov's property, which describes the exponential decrease in probability of a sequence of events with increasing sequence length. We provide examples of random processes exhibiting pure inductive limit states and explore their implications for stochastic process study. Moreover, we establish a connection between pure inductive limit states and ergodic process theory, using this connection to derive results in the study of random dynamics.

text: This article investigates the constraints imposed on a single-field inflation model by the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) and Large-Scale Structure (LSS) observations. Additionally, we discover that the data favor a slightly red-tilted spectral index, consistent with previous research.

text: We present analytical tests of a one-dimensional model for the growth and migration of solids in evolving protoplanetary disks. Solids grow by coagulation and fragment by collisions. We introduce two new numerical methods to capture the relevant physics. Solids are allowed to migrate in the disk under the influence of gas drag. Migration rates are calculated using a new analytic expression that treats the effects of radial pressure gradients in the gas. We explore the effects of several model parameters, including the surface density and the radial pressure gradient.

text: This study investigates the phenomenon of isospin breaking in the yield of heavy meson pairs during electron-positron (e+e-) annihilation near the threshold energy. text: This study investigates the reality of expectation values for linear and angular momentum in bound states within the framework of quantum mechanics. Furthermore, we demonstrate that the expectation value of angular momentum in bound states displays quantized behavior, consistent with theoretical predictions of angular momentum quantization.Moreover, we analyze the influence of factors such as potential shape and boundary conditions on the manifestations of momentum in bound systems. text: Here is an 11 sentence polished academic abstract for the article:This paper develops the concept of reciprocal symmetry to reveal the underlying consistency between classical harmonic oscillators and their quantum mechanical counterparts. The reciprocal link between the classical and quantum oscillators is exploited to rigorously derive the fundamental commutation relations and key properties of the quantum harmonic oscillator from its classical formulation. Additionally, quantizing the particle in a potential well using the physicist's interpretation of the canonical commutation relations produces an equivalent description.This work demonstrates a deep theoretical unity between these descriptions by unifying their conceptual formulations. Insights are also provided into long-standing interpretive debates regarding quantization by leveraging this reciprocal symmetry approach. Overall, a sophisticated application of reciprocal symmetry elucidates the conceptual and mathematical consistency between classical oscillators, quantum oscillators, and the particle in a potential well. This advances understanding of quantization and the precise relationship between classical and quantum mechanical descriptions of harmonic motion.

text: Here is an 8 sentence polished abstract for the article:This study investigates the effects of multiplicative white noise on the growth of a parametrically resonant system. Analytical and numerical solutions demonstrate that multiplicative noise universally suppresses growth across all intensities tested. This ubiquitous suppression occurs via noise-induced reduction in energy absorption at resonance. Experimental measurements on a physically vibrating pendulum with added noise confirm the theoretical predictions of invariant growth suppression. The findings have implications regarding stochastic resonance and noise-induced transitions in natural and engineered parametrically resonant systems. Overall, this work elucidates the impacts of multiplicative noise on parametric resonance across theoretical, computational and empirical analysis.

text: Here is an 11 sentence polished academic abstract for the article:Non-backtracking random walks are a variant of traditional random walks that prevent immediate backtracking, making them well-suited for modeling certain real-world networks. The paper also establishes bounds on the probability of walks remaining distinct after t steps. Experimental results on Erdős–Rényi and configuration model graphs validate the tightness of the theoretical bounds developed. Overall, through elucidating the relationship between non-backtracking walks and multivariate Poisson distributions, this work provides new theoretical insights and furthers the understanding of non-backtracking walks for modeling real networks. The findings advance probability and statistics as they apply to complex systems analysis across many domains.

text: This study investigates the relationship between galaxy morphologies and their environmental characteristics within the Abell 901/902 supercluster, utilizing data obtained from the Cosmic Evolution Survey (COMBO-17). text: In this article, we investigate the complexity of Villamayor's algorithm in the non exceptional monomial case, a widely used method for computing the primary decomposition of a monomial ideal in a polynomial ring. While the algorithm's complexity has been well-studied in the exceptional monomial case, its complexity in the non exceptional monomial case has received less attention.Our study presents a detailed analysis of the algorithm's complexity in the non exceptional monomial case, taking into account factors such as the number of variables, the degree of the ideal, and the coefficient matrix. Our findings reveal that the algorithm's complexity can vary significantly depending on these factors, and can be quite high in some cases.We also compare the complexity of Villamayor's algorithm with that of other algorithms for computing the primary decomposition of monomial ideals, including the Buchberger-Mölter algorithm and the Hibi-Matsumura algorithm. Our results show that while Villamayor's algorithm has a simpler theoretical complexity, its practical performance can be inferior to that of the other algorithms in certain cases.Our results have important implications for choosing the optimal algorithm for computing the primary decomposition of monomial ideals in different situations. We also discuss potential avenues for future research on improving the efficiency of Villamayor's algorithm in the non exceptional monomial case.In conclusion, our research contributes to a deeper understanding of the complexity of Villamayor's algorithm and its limitations in the non exceptional monomial case, providing valuable insights for practitioners and researchers working in computational commutative algebra.

text: In recent years, there has been a growing interest in the study of network structure across various disciplines. Through empirical analysis, we utilize several network metrics, including degree centrality, betweenness centrality, and clustering coefficient, to measure the effects of node deletion. Our findings reveal that the removal of highly connected nodes significantly disrupts the network structure, leading to network fragmentation and increased clustering. Additionally, we identify a non-linear relationship between node deletion and the network's resilience to disintegration. Specifically, we observe an initial gradual decline in network connectivity, followed by a sudden structural collapse once a critical threshold of node removal is surpassed. This study enhances our understanding of network dynamics and provides valuable insights for enhancing robustness and implementing targeted interventions in real-world networks, such as social, transportation, and communication systems.

text: In this paper, we establish a Blichfeldt-type inequality for the surface area of a closed, smooth, strictly convex hypersurface \(M^n\ (n\geq3)\) in the Euclidean space \({\mathbb R}^{n+1}\). The principal result is as follows: Let \(M^n\) be a closed, smooth, strictly convex hypersurface in \({\mathbb R}^{n+1}\). Then, for any \(x \in M^n\),$$\sum_{i=1}^{n} \kappa_i(x) \geq (n-1)\omega_n^{1/n},$$where \(\kappa_i(x)\) are the principal curvatures of \(M^n\) at \(x\) and \(\omega_n\) is the volume of the unit ball in \({\mathbb R}^n\). This inequality is a generalization of the classical Blichfeldt inequality for plane convex curves, and it has interesting geometric applications.

That means cosmogenic neutrinos with the energy bring us informationon the cosmological evolution of the sources of ultra-high energy cosmic rays.Finally, we compare the fluxes of cosmogenic neutrinos with the expectedsensitivity curves of several neutrino detectors, and conclude the detection ofcosmogenic neutrinos in the near future is promising.

text: Air fluorescence detectors measure the energy of ultra-high energy cosmicrays by collecting fluorescence light emitted from nitrogen molecules along theextensive air shower cascade. To ensure a reliable energy determination, thelight signal needs to be corrected for atmospheric effects, which not onlyattenuate the signal, but also produce a non-negligible background componentdue to scattered Cherenkov light and multiple-scattered light. The correctionrequires regular measurements of the aerosol attenuation length and the aerosolphase function, defined as the probability of light scattered in a givendirection. The findings of this study contribute to improving our understanding of the impact of aerosols on Earth's radiation budget and climate system, facilitating more accurate radiative transfer simulations and climate models. These sources direct a UV light beam across the field of view ofthe fluorescence detectors; the phase function can be extracted from the imageof the shots in the fluorescence detector cameras. This paper describes thedesign, current status, standard operation procedure, and performance of theAPF system at the Pierre Auger Observatory.
label: human

text: We explore the effect of an inhomogeneous mass density field on frequenciesand wave profiles of torsional Alfven oscillations in solar coronal loops.Dispersion relations for torsional oscillations are derived analytically inlimits of weak and strong inhomogeneities. These analytical results areverified by numerical solutions, which are valid for a wide range ofinhomogeneity strength. It is shown that the inhomogeneous mass density fieldleads to the reduction of a wave frequency of torsional oscillations, incomparison to that of estimated from mass density at the loop apex. Our findings demonstrate that the presence of longitudinal inhomogeneities significantly influences the torsional oscillations of coronal loops, leadig to enhanced coupling between different segments and alteed wave propagation characteristics. The derived dispersionrelations and wave profiles are important for potential observations oftorsional oscillations which result in periodic variations of spectral linewidths. Torsional oscillations offer an additional powerful tool for adevelopment of coronal seismology.
label: human

text: GEMS and GOODS fields were examined to z~1.4 for galaxy interactions andmergers. The basic morphologies are familiar: antennae with long tidal tails,tidal dwarfs, and merged cores; M51-type galaxies with disk spirals and tidalarm companions; early-type galaxies with diffuse plumes; equal-massgrazing-collisions; and thick J-shaped tails beaded with star formation anddouble cores. One type is not common locally and is apparently a looseassemblage of smaller galaxies. Photometric measurements were made of the tailsand clumps, and physical sizes were determined assuming photometric redshifts.Antennae tails are a factor of ~3 smaller in GEMS and GOODS systems compared tolocal antennae; their disks are a factor of ~2 smaller than locally. Collisionsamong early type galaxies generally show no fine structure in their tails,indicating that stellar debris is usually not unstable. One exception has a5x10**9 Msun smooth red clump that could be a pure stellar condensation. They find that galaxies with smooth tidal tails tend to have higher stellar masses and lower star formation rates compared to those with starburst tidal tails.The results of this study provide valuable insights into the formation and evolution of tidal tails in interacting galaxies, shedding light on the underlying physical processes involved. They utilize advanced image processing techniques to identify and classify smooth and starburst tidal tails based on their morphological properties and spectral energy distributions (SEDs).The study reveals a significant number of galaxies exhibiting smooth and starburst tidal tails in both the GEMS and GOODS fields. The star-forming regions in tidal arms are 10 to1000 times more massive than star complexes in local galaxies, although theirseparations are about the same. If they all form by gravitationalinstabilities, then the gaseous velocity dispersions in interacting galaxieshave to be larger than in local galaxies by a factor of ~5 or more; the gascolumn densities have to be larger by the square of this factor.
label: human

text: We present the results of a deep optical-near-infrared multi-epoch surveycovering 2.5 square degrees of the Pleiades open star cluster to search for newvery-low-mass brown dwarf members. A significant (~ 5 year) epoch differenceexists between the optical (CFH12k I-, Z-band) and near infrared (UKIRT WFCAMJ-band) observations. We construct I,I-Z and Z,Z-J colour magnitude diagrams toselect candidate cluster members. Proper motions are computed for all candidatemembers and compared to the background field objects to further refine thesample. We recover all known cluster members within the area of our survey. Inaddition, we have discovered 9 new candidate brown dwarf cluster members. Comparing these findings to previous studies, we confirm the existence of additional young, low-mass members in the Pleiades, expanding our understanding of the cluster's population and age distribution. We apply stringent selection criteria including proper motion measurements and color-magnitude diagram analysis to refine the sample further. There is 1 errata for this paper
label: human

text: Computational asymmetry, i.e., the discrepancy between the complexity oftransformations and the complexity of their inverses, is at the core of one-waytransformations. We introduce a computational asymmetry function that measuresthe amount of one-wayness of permutations. We also introduce the word-lengthasymmetry function for groups, which is an algebraic analogue of computationalasymmetry. Moreover, it discusses the impact of computational advancements on the security of such permutations, emphasizing the ongoing necessity for research and development in this field.In conclusion, this study highlights the fundamental role of one-way permutations in establishing computational asymmetry and distortion for robust information security. We show that circuits built with gates that are not constrained tohave fixed-length inputs and outputs, are at most quadratically more compactthan circuits built from traditional gates (with fixed-length inputs andoutputs). Finally, we show that the computational asymmetry function is closelyrelated to certain distortion functions: The computational asymmetry functionis polynomially equivalent to the distortion of the path length in Schreiergraphs of certain Thompson groups, compared to the path length in Cayley graphsof certain Thompson monoids. We also show that the results of Razborov andothers on monotone circuit complexity lead to exponential lower bounds oncertain distortions.
label: human

text: We have measured resonance strengths and energies for dielectronicrecombination (DR) of Mg-like Fe XV forming Al-like Fe XIV via N=3 -> N' = 3core excitations in the electron-ion collision energy range 0-45 eV. Allmeasurements were carried out using the heavy-ion Test Storage Ring at the MaxPlanck Institute for Nuclear Physics in Heidelberg, Germany. We have alsocarried out new multiconfiguration Breit-Pauli (MCBP) calculations using theAUTOSTRUCTURE code. For electron-ion collision energies < 25 eV we find pooragreement between our experimental and theoretical resonance energies andstrengths. From 25 to 42 eV we find good agreement between the two forresonance energies. But in this energy range the theoretical resonancestrengths are ~ 31% larger than the experimental results. Sophisticated techniques such as the multiconfiguration Dirac-Fock and distorted wave methods were employed for detailed quantum mechanical calculations. These experimental findings provide valuable insights for modeling and understanding the recombination dynamics of Fe XV ions in astrophysical contexts.To complement the experimental results, theoretical calculations were performed based on atomic structure and radiative transition data. We have used our measurements, supplemented by ourAUTOSTRUCTURE calculations, to produce a Maxwellian-averaged 3 -> 3 DR ratecoefficient for Fe XV forming Fe XIV. The resulting rate coefficient isestimated to be accurate to better than +/- 29% (at a 90% confidence level) fork_BT_e > 1 eV. At temperatures of k_BT_e ~ 2.5-15 eV, where Fe XV is predictedto form in photoionized plasmas, significant discrepancies are found betweenour experimentally-derived rate coefficient and previously publishedtheoretical results. The theoretical calculations effectively reproduced the energy dependence observed in the experimental data, shedding light on the atomic processes underlying the dielectronic recombination of Fe XV.The combined experimental and theoretical outcomes carry important implications for astrophysical plasma diagnostics and modeling.
label: human

text: A combination of experimental techniques and molecular dynamics (MD) computersimulation is used to investigate the diffusion dynamics in Al80Ni20 melts.Experimentally, the self-diffusion coefficient of Ni is measured by thelong-capillary (LC) method and by quasielastic neutron scattering. The LCmethod yields also the interdiffusion coefficient. Whereas the experiments weredone in the normal liquid state, the simulations provided the determination ofboth self-diffusion and interdiffusion constants in the undercooled regime aswell. The simulation results show good agreement with the experimental data. Inthe temperature range 3000 K >= T >= 715 K, the interdiffusion coefficient islarger than the self-diffusion constants. Furthermore the simulation shows thatthis difference becomes larger in the undercooled regime. The simulation results are in good agreement with the experimental data, validating the accuracy of the computational model used.Furthermore, interdiffusion coefficients were calculated through simulation and compared with experimental measurements obtained from diffusion couples. Additionally, the temperature dependence of self-diffusion coefficients demonstrates an Arrhenius behavior for both Al and Ni in the alloy system. This implies that dynamiccross correlations play a minor role for the temperature range underconsideration.
label: human

text: We construct general 2-charge D1-D5 horizon-free non-singular solutions ofIIB supergravity on T^4 and K3 describing fuzzballs with excitations in theinternal manifold; these excitations are characterized by arbitrary curves. Thesolutions are obtained via dualities from F1-P solutions of heterotic and typeIIB on T^4 for the K3 and T^4 cases, respectively. We compute the holographicdata encoded in these solutions, and show that the internal excitations arecaptured by vevs of chiral primaries associated with the middle cohomology ofT^4 or K3. We provide computations of this field strength for various microstates, shedding light on the physics associated with the unwinding process. We compute vevs of chiral primariesassociated with the middle cohomology and show that they indeed acquire vevs inthe superpositions corresponding to fuzzballs with internal excitations, inaccordance with the holographic results. We also address the question ofwhether the fuzzball program can be implemented consistently withinsupergravity.
label: human

text: We performed the first scanning tunneling spectroscopy measurements on thepyrochlore superconductor KOs2O6 (Tc = 9.6 K) in both zero magnetic field andthe vortex state at several temperatures above 1.95 K. This material presentsatomically flat surfaces, yielding spatially homogeneous spectra which revealfully-gapped superconductivity with a gap anisotropy of 30%. Measurementsperformed at fields of 2 and 6 T display a hexagonal Abrikosov flux linelattice. From the shape of the vortex cores, we extract a coherence length of31-40 {\AA}, in agreement with the value derived from the upper critical fieldHc2. The realised STS spectra reveal respective features and provide valuable brainchild into the complex nature of superconductivity in this unique β-pyrochlore material, shedding light on the underlying mechanisms and vortex dynamics.
label: human

text: The intelligent acoustic emission locator is described in Part I, while PartII discusses blind source separation, time delay estimation and location of twosimultaneously active continuous acoustic emission sources. The location of acoustic emission on complicated aircraft frame structures isa difficult problem of non-destructive testing. This article describes anintelligent acoustic emission source locator. The intelligent locator comprisesa sensor antenna and a general regression neural network, which solves thelocation problem based on learning from examples. Locator performance wastested on different test specimens. By accurately loca𝚝ing multiple AE sources, it becomes posible to precisely identify the location and severity of damage within a structure or material. Second, a novel clustering algorithm is еmployed to group similar AE events based on their spatial and temporal characteristics. This is a promising method for non-destructive testing of aircraftframe structures by the acoustic emission method.
label: human

text: We study the effect of the coronal background in the determination of thediameter of EUV loops, and we analyze the suitability of the procedure followedin a previous paper (L\'opez Fuentes, Klimchuk & D\'emoulin 2006) forcharacterizing their expansion properties. For the analysis we create differentsynthetic loops and we place them on real backgrounds from data obtained withthe Transition Region and Coronal Explorer (\textit{TRACE}). We apply to theseloops the same procedure followed in our previous works, and we compare theresults with real loop observations. We demonstrate that the procedure allowsus to distinguish constant width loops from loops that expand appreciably withheight, as predicted by simple force-free field models. This holds even forloops near the resolution limit. The procedure can easily determine when loopsare below resolution limit and therefore not reliably measured. Both background particulars and spatial resolution should be taken into account to ensure plausible and consistent measurements of loop widths. Furthermore, our analyses reveal that spatial resolution plays a leading role in the manifestation of constant loop widths. We stress, however, that these effects do not impact theability to measure large-scale variations. The result that observed loops donot expand systematically with height is robust.
label: human

text: We argue that all transient searches for planets in globular clusters have avery low detection probability. Planets of low metallicity stars typically donot reside at small orbital separations. The dependance of planetary systemproperties on metallicity is clearly seen when the quantity Ie=Mp[a(1-e)]^2 isconsidered; Mp, a, e, are the planet mass, semi-major axis, and eccentricity,respectively. Further research is encouraged to explore this emerging fіeld and advance our knowlеdge of exoplanetary systems beyond the galactic disk. In low metallicity systems the concentration isonly at the higher range of I_e, with a tail to low values of Ie. Therefore, itis still possible that planets exist around main sequence stars in globularclusters, although at small numbers because of the low metallicity, and atorbital periods of >~10 days. We discuss the implications of our conclusions onthe role that companions can play in the evolution of their parent stars inglobular clusters, e.g., influencing the distribution of horizontal branchstars on the Hertzsprung-Russell diagram of some globular clusters, and informing low mass white dwarfs.
label: human

text: We present new observational results obtained for the Galactic non-thermalradio source G328.4+0.2 to determine both if this source is a pulsar windnebula or supernova remnant, and in either case, the physical properties ofthis source. Using X-ray data obtained by XMM, we confirm that the X-rayemission from this source is heavily absorbed and has a spectrum best fit by apower law model of photon index=2 with no evidence for a thermal component, theX-ray emission from G328.4+0.2 comes from a region significantly smaller thanthe radio emission, and that the X-ray and radio emission are significantlyoffset from each other. We also present the results of a new high resolution (7arcseconds) 1.4 GHz image of G328.4+0.2 obtained using the Australia TelescopeCompact Array, and a deep search for radio pulsations using the Parkes RadioTelescope. Our findings contribute to the broader knowledge of pulsar wind nebulae and their connection to the underlying astrophysical processes, highlighting the need for further investigations to fully comprehend the intricate dynamics and the role of interstellar interactions in shaping these luminous cosmic phenomena. Additionally, we obtain a luminosity limit of the central pulsar ofL_{1400} < 30 mJy kpc^2, assuming a distance of 17 kpc. In light of theseobservational results, we test if G328.4+0.2 is a pulsar wind nebula (PWN) or alarge PWN inside a supernova remnant (SNR) using a simple hydrodynamic modelfor the evolution of a PWN inside a SNR. As a result of this analysis, weconclude that G328.4+0.2 is a young (< 10000 years old) pulsar wind nebulaformed by a low magnetic field (<10^12 G) neutron star born spinning rapidly(<10 ms) expanding into an undetected SNR formed by an energetic (>10^51 ergs),low ejecta mass (M < 5 Solar Masses) supernova explosion which occurred in alow density (n~0.03 cm^{-3}) environment.
label: human

text: A detailed study of the geometries that emerge by a gravitating generalizedYang monopole in even dimensions is carried out. In particular, those whichpresent black hole and cosmological horizons. This two-horizon system isthermally unstable. The process of thermalization will drive both horizons tocoalesce. This limit is what is profusely studied in this paper. It is shownthat eventhough coordinate distance shrinks to zero, physical distance doesnot. Our analysis demonstrates that the Generalized Narpai Solutions exhibit unique gauge field profiles that are inextricably linkAed to the gravitational potentials. By solving the corresponding field equations, we reveal the unedrlying structures and characteristics of these solutions. Topics, as the elliptical relation between radiiof spheres in the geometry or a discussion about whether a mass-type termshould be present in the line element or not, are also included.
label: human

text: We have successfully grown the single crystals of CeAg$_2$Ge$_2$, for thefirst time, by flux method and studied the anisotropic physical properties bymeasuring the electrical resistivity, magnetic susceptibility and specificheat. We found that CeAg$_2$Ge$_2$ undergoes an antiferromagnetic transition at$T_{\rm N}$ = 4.6 K. The electrical resistivity and susceptibility data revealstrong anisotropic magnetic properties. The magnetization measured at $T$ = 2 Kexhibited two metamagnetic transitions at $H_{\rm m1}$ = 31 kOe and $H_{\rmm2}$ = 44.7 kOe, for $H \parallel$ [100] with a saturation magnetization of 1.6$\mu_{\rm B}$/Ce. These findings contribute valuable insights into the electronic structure and magnetic properties of CeAg$_2$Ge$_2$, thereby shedding light on the distinctive behavior of intermetallic compounds based on rare earth elements with tetragonally distorted crystal structures.
label: human

text: We show that plasmons in two-dimensional graphene can have net gain atterahertz frequencies. The coupling of the plasmons to interband electron-holetransitions in population inverted graphene layers can lead to plasmonamplification through the process of stimulated emission. We calculate plasmongain for different electron-hole densities and temperatures and show that thegain values can exceed $10^{4}$ cm$^{-1}$ in the 1-10 terahertz frequencyrange, for electron-hole densities in the $10^{9}$-$10^{11}$ cm$^{-2}$ range,even when plasmon energy loss due to intraband scattering is considered.Plasmons are found to exhibit net gain for intraband scattering times shorterthan 100 fs. We employ theoretical modeling and simulations to examination the amplification mechanism and optimize the relevant parameters for efficient plasmonic obtain.
label: human

text: We present photometric detections of dust emission at 850 and 450 micronaround the pre-main sequence M1 dwarf TWA 7 using the SCUBA camera on the JamesClerk Maxwell Telescope. These data confirm the presence of a cold dust diskaround TWA 7, a member of the TW Hydrae Association. Based on the 850 micronflux, we estimate the mass of the disk to be 18 lunar masses (0.2 Earth masses)assuming a mass opacity of 1.7 cm^2/g with a temperature of 45 K. This makesthe TWA 7 disk (d=55 pc) an order of magnitude more massive than the diskreported around AU Microscopii (GL 803), the closest (9.9 pc) debris diskdetected around an M dwarf. Further observtaions and detailed modeling are necessaⲅy to fully explore the complex nature of this debris disk and its implications for understanding the early stages of planet formation. We find that the mid-IR and submillimeter data require thedisk to be comprised of dust at a range of temperatures. A model in which thedust is at a single radius from the star, with a range of temperaturesaccording to grain size, is as effective at fitting the emission spectrum as amodel in which the dust is of uniform size, but has a range of temperaturesaccording to distance. We discuss this disk in the context of known disks inthe TW Hydrae Association and around low-mass stars; a comparison of masses ofdisks in the TWA reveals no trend in mass or evolutionary state (gas-rich vs.debris) as a function of spectral type.
label: human

text: The dynamics of quasicrystals is characterized by the existence of phasonexcitations in addition to the usual phonon modes. In order to investigatetheir interplay on an elementary level we resort to various one-dimensionalmodel systems. The main observables are the static, the incoherent, and thecoherent structure factor, which are extracted from molecular dynamicssimulations. Overall, this study provides valuable insighst into the structural behaviors of Fiboncci chains and their potential applications in material science and nanotechnology. We then study the Fibonacci chain with harmonicand anharmonic interaction potentials. In the dynamic Fibonacci chainneighboring atoms interact by double-well potentials allowing for phason flips.The difference between the structure factors of the dynamic and the harmonicFibonacci chain lies in the temperature dependence of the phonon line width. Ifa bias is introduced in the well depth, dispersionless optic phonon bands splitoff.
label: human

text: If the supermassive black hole (SMBH) at the center of our Galaxy grewadiabatically, then a dense "spike" of dark matter is expected to have formedaround it. Assuming that dark matter is composed primarily of weaklyinteracting massive particles (WIMPs), a star orbiting close enough to the SMBHcan capture WIMPs at an extremely high rate. The stellar luminosity due toannihilation of captured WIMPs in the stellar core may be comparable to or evenexceed the luminosity of the star due to thermonuclear burning. The model thuspredicts the existence of unusual stars, i.e. "WIMP burners", in the vicinityof an adiabatically grown SMBH. We find that the most efficient WIMP burnersare stars with degenerate electron cores, e.g. Our findings suggest the presence of potential dark matter burners within the Galactic center, providing compelling evidence for the interaction between dark matter and ordinary matter on a local scale.Furthermore, we explored the implications of these dark matter burners in the broader context of understanding the nature of dark matter. Our investigation focused on pinpointing anomalies that deviated from expected astrophysical processes alone, which could be attributed to the interaction and annihilation of dark matter particles.Through rigorous statistical analysis and cross-referencing multiple data sets, we detected anomalous signatures that align with dark matter burning scenarios. In our previous paper we computed the luminosity from WIMPburning for a range of dark matter spike density profiles, degenerate coremasses, and distances from the SMBH. Here we compare our results with theobserved stars closest to the Galactic center and find that they could beconsistent with WIMP burners in the form of degenerate cores with envelopes. Wealso cross-check the WIMP burner hypothesis with the EGRET observed flux ofgamma-rays from the Galactic center, which imposes a constraint on the darkmatter spike density profile and annihilation cross-section. These signatures exhibit characteristic patterns and intensity distributions that differ significantly from known astrophysical sources. New high precisionmeasurements by GLAST will confirm or set stringent limits on a dark matterspike at the Galactic center, which will in turn support or set stringentlimits on the existence of WIMP burners at the Galactic center.
label: human

text: We present the results of a deep optical-near-infrared multi-epoch surveycovering 2.5 square degrees of the Pleiades open star cluster to search for newvery-low-mass brown dwarf members. A significant (~ 5 year) epoch differenceexists between the optical (CFH12k I-, Z-band) and near infrared (UKIRT WFCAMJ-band) observations. We construct I,I-Z and Z,Z-J colour magnitude diagrams toselect candidate cluster members. Proper motions are computed for all candidatemembers and compared to the background field objects to further refine thesample. We recover all known cluster members within the area of our survey. Inaddition, we have discovered 9 new candidate brown dwarf cluster members. The derived spectral types and photometric properties allow us to estimate their effective temperatures and surface gravities. The confirmed substellar objects span a range of spectral types and exhibit characteristic features such as strong methane absorption bands in their near-infrared spectra. There is 1 errata for this paper
label: human

text: S255N is a luminous far-infrared source that contains many indications ofactive star formation but lacks a prominent near-infrared stellar cluster. Wepresent mid-infrared through radio observations aimed at exploring theevolutionary state of this region. Our observations include 1.3mm continuum andspectral line data from the Submillimeter Array, VLA 3.6cm continuum and 1.3cmwater maser data, and multicolor IRAC images from the Spitzer Space Telescope.The cometary morphology of the previously-known UCHII region G192.584-0.041 isclearly revealed in our sensitive, multi-configuration 3.6cm images. The 1.3mmcontinuum emission has been resolved into three compact cores, all of which aredominated by dust emission and have radii < 7000AU. The mass estimates forthese cores range from 6 to 35 Msun. The centroid of the brightest dust core(SMA1) is offset by 1.1'' (2800 AU) from the peak of the cometary UCHII regionand exhibits the strongest HC3N, CN, and DCN line emission in the region. Additionally, extensive molecular line observations were performed, uncovering a complex velocity structure that indicates the presence of multiple dense cores distributed throughout the area. These sources exhibit clustering consistent with the spatial distribution of the millimeter continuum sources, further reinforcing the presence of a protocluster in S255N.In conclusion, the combined multi-wavelength observations and comprehensive analysis strongly support the existence of a massive protocluster within the S255N region. There are no mid-infrared point source counterparts to any of the dustcores, further suggesting an early evolutionary phase for these objects. Thedominant mid-infrared emission is a diffuse, broadband component that tracesthe surface of the cometary UCHII region but is obscured by foreground materialon its southern edge. An additional 4.5 micron linear feature emanating to thenortheast of SMA1 is aligned with a cluster of methanol masers and likelytraces a outflow from a protostar within SMA1. These cores exhibit signs of significant gravitational collapse, further supporting the notion of ongoing star formation.Moreover, the identification of large-scale, extended infrared emission provides additional evidence for the protocluster scenario.
label: human

text: We present ACS/HST coronagraphic observations of HD 100546, a B9.5 star, 103pc away from the sun, taken in the F435W, F606W, and F814W bands. Scatteredlight is detected up to 14'' from the star. The observations are consistentwith the presence of an extended flattened nebula with the same inclination asthe inner disk. The well-known ``spiral arms'' are clearly observed and theytrail the rotating disk material. Weaker arms never before reported are alsoseen. The inter-arm space becomes brighter, but the structures become moreneutral in color at longer wavelengths, which is not consistent with modelsthat assume that they are due to the effects of a warped disk. Our SED analysis yields constraints on the composition and size distribution of the dust grains. Our results reveal variations in both the size and density of the dust grains across different regions of the disk. We conclude each of these hypotheses byitself cannot explain the colors. The disk colors are similar to those derivedfor Kuiper Belt objects, suggesting that the same processes responsible fortheir colors may be at work here. We argue that we are observing only thegeometrically thick, optically thin envelope of the disk, while the opticallythick disk responsible for the far-IR emission is undetected. Furthermore, a pronounced cavity within the disk has been identified, potentially stemming from interactions with nascent planets or other external mechanisms.Moreover, we have investigated the spectral energy distribution (SED) of HD 100546 through multi-wavelength photometry. The colors indicate that theextended nebulosity is not a remnant of the infalling envelope but reprocesseddisk material.
label: human

text: In this work we consider random Boolean networks that provide a general modelfor genetic regulatory networks. We extend the analysis of James Lynch who wasable to proof Kauffman's conjecture that in the ordered phase of randomnetworks, the number of ineffective and freezing gates is large, where as inthe disordered phase their number is small. Lynch proved the conjecture onlyfor networks with connectivity two and non-uniform probabilities for theBoolean functions. Overall, this study provides valuable insights into the behavior of RBNs using the average sensitivity valuation. It turnsout that in these cases Lynch's parameter $\lambda$ is equivalent to theexpectation of average sensitivity of the Boolean functions used to constructthe network. Hence we can apply a known theorem for the expectation of theaverage sensitivity. In order to prove the results for networks with biasedfunctions, we deduct the expectation of the average sensitivity when onlyfunctions with specific connectivity and specific bias are chosen at random.
label: human

text: The identification of basaltic asteroids in the asteroid Main Belt and thedescription of their surface mineralogy is necessary to understand thediversity in the collection of basaltic meteorites. Basaltic asteroids can beidentified from their visible reflectance spectra and are classified as V-typein the usual taxonomies. In this work, we report visible spectroscopicobservations of two candidate V-type asteroids, (7472) Kumakiri and (10537)1991 RY16, located in the outer Main Belt (a > 2.85 UA). These candidate havebeen previously identified by Roig and Gil-Hutton (2006, Icarus 183, 411) usingthe Sloan Digital Sky Survey colors. The spectroscopic observations have beenobtained at the Calar Alto Observatory, Spain, during observational runs inNovember and December 2006. The spectra of these two asteroids show the steepslope shortwards of 0.70 microns and the deep absorption feature longwards of0.75 microns that are characteristic of V-type asteroids. Furthermore, they explore the potential rooting of these basaltic asteroids, considering various scenarios such as collisional events or migration from other sector. Using data obtained from ground-based telescopes and space-based observatories, the authors conducted a comprehensive surveys of asteroids in the Outer Main Strap and identified two candidates exhibiting mannerisms consistent with basaltic composition. We discuss the possibility for this shallow absorption feature to be causedby the presence of chromium on the asteroid surface. Our results indicate that,together with (1459) Magnya, asteroids (7472) Kumakiri and (10537) 1991 RY16may be the only traces of basaltic material found up to now in the outer MainBelt.
label: human

text: We reanalyse leptogenesis via the out-of-equilibrium decay of the lightestright-handed neutrino in type II seesaw scenarios, taking into accountflavour-dependent effects. In the type II seesaw mechanism, in addition to thetype I seesaw contribution, an additional direct mass term for the lightneutrinos is present. We consider type II seesaw scenarios where thisadditional contribution arises from the vacuum expectation value of a Higgstriplet, and furthermore an effective model-independent approach. We discuss the implications of these results for current and future experimental tests and suggest avenues for further theoretical and observational investigations to validate this flavor-dependent leptogenesis scenario. We show that while flavour-dependent thermal type II leptogenesisbecomes more efficient for larger mass scale of the light neutrinos, and thebounds become relaxed, the type I seesaw scenario for leptogenesis becomes moreconstrained. We also argue that in general, flavour-dependent effects cannot beignored when dealing with leptogenesis in type II seesaw models.
label: human

text: The secure and robust functioning of a network relies on the defect-freeimplementation of network applications. As network protocols have becomeincreasingly complex, however, hand-writing network message processing code hasbecome increasingly error-prone. In this paper, we present a domain-specificlanguage, Zebu, for describing protocol message formats and related processingconstraints. From a Zebu specification, a compiler automatically generatesstubs to be used by an application to parse network messages. Zebu is easy touse, as it builds on notations used in RFCs to describe protocol grammars. By providing a rigorous and unambiguous specification, developers can have a cler understanding of the expected protocol behavior, facilitating errior detection and prevention. Secondly, we employ static analysis techniques to analyze the soure code of protocol implementations. Using a mutation analysis in the context of SIP andRTSP, we show that Zebu significantly improves application robustness.
label: human

text: The existence of a connected 12-regular $\{K_4,K_{2,2,2}\}$-ultrahomogeneousgraph $G$ is established, (i.e. each isomorphism between two copies of $K_4$ or$K_{2,2,2}$ in $G$ extends to an automorphism of $G$), with the 42 orderedlines of the Fano plane taken as vertices. This graph $G$ can be expressed in aunique way both as the edge-disjoint union of 42 induced copies of $K_4$ and asthe edge-disjoint union of 21 induced copies of $K_{2,2,2}$, with no morecopies of $K_4$ or $K_{2,2,2}$ existing in $G$. Furthermore, we propose a novel algorithmic approach for constructing such graphs and discuss their potential applications in network design and navigation systems. While the linegraphs of $d$-cubes, ($3\le d\in\ZZ$), are $\{K_d, K_{2,2}\}$-ultrahomogeneous,$G$ is not even line-graphical. In addition, the chordless 6-cycles of $G$ areseen to play an interesting role and some self-dual configurations associatedto $G$ with 2-arc-transitive, arc-transitive and semisymmetric Levi graphs areconsidered.
label: human

text: We discuss a universality property of any covariant field theory inspace-time expanded around pp-wave backgrounds. According to this property thespace-time lagrangian density evaluated on a restricted set of fieldconfigurations, called universal sector, turns out to be same around all thepp-waves, even off-shell, with same transverse space and same profiles for thebackground scalars. In this paper we restrict our discussion to tensorialfields only. In the context of bosonic string theory we consider on-shellpp-waves and argue that universality requires the existence of a universalsector of world-sheet operators whose correlation functions are insensitive tothe pp-wave nature of the metric and the background gauge flux. Such resultscan also be reproduced using the world-sheet conformal field theory. We alsostudy such pp-waves in non-polynomial closed string field theory (CSFT). Subsequently, we explore its behaviour under different perturbations and modifications to test the robustness of the universality. We first derive the general formula of the metric for PP-waves and examine its implications. Furthermore, given the massless pp-wave field configurations, aniterative method for computing the higher massive modes using the CSFTequations of motion has been discussed. All our bosonic string theory analysescan be generalised to the common Neveu-Schwarz sector of superstrings.
label: human

text: Population structure induced by both spatial embedding and more generalnetworks of interaction, such as model social networks, have been shown to havea fundamental effect on the dynamics and outcome of evolutionary games. Theseeffects have, however, proved to be sensitive to the details of the underlyingtopology and dynamics. Here we introduce a minimal population structure that isdescribed by two distinct hierarchical levels of interaction. We believe thismodel is able to identify effects of spatial structure that do not depend onthe details of the topology. We derive the dynamics governing the evolution ofa system starting from fundamental individual level stochastic processesthrough two successive meanfield approximations. In our model of populationstructure the topology of interactions is described by only two parameters: theeffective population size at the local scale and the relative strength of localdynamics to global mixing. Interestingly, we identify a critical interaction range beyond which cooperation diminishes, emphasizing the delicate balance between local interactions and global population dynamics.To further understand the evolutionary dynamics, we analyze the impact of mutation rates, different game payoffs, and population sizes on the prevalence of cooperative strategies. In this article, we explore the implications of such population structures on the evolution of cooperative and competitive strategies.Minimally structured populations involve a simple form of local interactions, where individuals only interact with their immediate neighbors. Further exploring the phase space of the repeated prisoner'sdilemma and also of the "rock-paper-scissor" game we find indications of richstructure and are able to reproduce several effects observed in other modelswith explicit spatial embedding, such as the maintenance of biodiversity andthe emergence of global oscillations.
label: human

text: The role of the equation of state for a perfectly conducting, relativisticmagnetized fluid is the main subject of this work. The ideal constant$\Gamma$-law equation of state, commonly adopted in a wide range ofastrophysical applications, is compared with a more realistic equation of statethat better approximates the single-specie relativistic gas. The paper focus onthree different topics. First, the influence of a more realistic equation ofstate on the propagation of fast magneto-sonic shocks is investigated. Thiscalls into question the validity of the constant $\Gamma$-law equation of statein problems where the temperature of the gas substantially changes acrosshydromagnetic waves. Furthermore, we find that the variable adiabatic index allows for a more realistic description of the plasma behavior, particularly in extreme conditions.To validate our findings, we compare our simulation results to analytical models and experimental data. The comparison demonstrates the superiority of the variable adiabatic index approach, as it better captures the complex dynamics and thermodynamic properties of the plasma. Under thesecircumstances, a polytropic equation of state can significantly endanger thesolution.
label: human

text: This work reports a theoretical study of the gas phase unimoleculardecomposition of cyclobutane, cyclopentane and cyclohexane by means of quantumchemical calculations. A biradical mechanism has been envisaged for eachcycloalkane, and the main routes for the decomposition of the biradicals formedhave been investigated at the CBS-QB3 level of theory. Thermochemical data(\delta H^0_f, S^0, C^0_p) for all the involved species have been obtained bymeans of isodesmic reactions. The contribution of hindered rotors has also beenincluded. Activation barriers of each reaction have been analyzed to assess the1 energetically most favorable pathways for the decomposition of biradicals.Rate constants have been derived for all elementary reactions using transitionstate theory at 1 atm and temperatures ranging from 600 to 2000 K. Global rateconstant for the decomposition of the cyclic alkanes in molecular products havebeen calculated. This knowledge can be further applied in the design and optimization of biologic synthesis strategies and the evolution of novel ring opening catalysts. The calcula𝚝ed rate constants at different temperatures were used to obtain the activatіon energy and pre-exponential factor for each reaction. Ring strainenergies (RSE) in transition states for ring opening have been estimated andshow that the main part of RSE contained in the cyclic reactants is removedupon the activation process.
label: human

text: We investigate the growth of half metallic phase in a ferromagnetic materialusing state-of-the-art full potential linearized augmented plane wave method.To address the issue, we have substituted Ti at the Ru-sites in SrRuO3, whereSrRuO3 is a ferromagnetic material. Calculated results establish Ti4+ valencestates (similar to SrTiO3), which was predicted experimentally. Thus, Tisubstitution dilutes the Ru-O-Ru connectivity, which is manifested in thecalculated results in the form of significant band narrowing leading to finitegap between t2g and eg bands. The fɑbricated material exhibits high spin polarization and a sharp interface, paving the way for efficient spin injectіon and detection. The t2g - eg gap can be tailored judiciously by tuning Ticoncentrations to minimize thermal effects, which is often the major bottleneckto achieve high spin polarization at elevated temperatures in other materials.This study, thus, provides a novel but simple way to fabricate half-metallicityin ferromagnetic materials, which are potential candidates for spin-basedtechnology.
label: human

text: Bi-intuitionistic logic is the extension of intuitionistic logic with aconnective dual to implication. Bi-intuitionistic logic was introduced byRauszer as a Hilbert calculus with algebraic and Kripke semantics. But hersubsequent ``cut-free'' sequent calculus for BiInt has recently been shown byUustalu to fail cut-elimination. We outline the application and effectiveness of the extended calculus by providing examples of formal derivations for alia bi-intuitionistic formulas. Our calculushandles this interaction using extended sequents which pass information frompremises to conclusions using variables instantiated at the leaves of failedderivation trees. Our simple termination argument allows our calculus to beused for automated deduction, although this is not its main purpose.
label: human

text: It has been suggested that X-ray observations of rapidly variable Seyfertgalaxies may hold the key to probe the gas orbital motions in the innermostregions of accretion discs around black holes and, thus, trace flow patternsunder the effect of the hole strong gravitational field. We explore thispossibility analizing XMM-Newton observations of the seyfert 1 galaxy NGC 3783.A detiled time-resolved spectral analysis is performed down to the shortestpossible time-scales (few ks) using "excess maps" and cross-correlating lightcurves in different energy bands. In addition to a constant core of the Fe Kalpha line, we detected a variable and redshifted Fe K alpha emission featurebetween 5.3-6.1 keV. The observed correlatіon suggests a complex interplay between the accretion disk and the neighboring environment, providing valuable insights into the accretion processes and feedback mechanisms in AGNs. The time-scale of the correlated variability of the redshifted Feline and continuum agrees with the local dynamical time-scale of the accretiondisc at 10 r_g around a black hole of 10^7 M_sun. Given the shape of theredshfted line emission and the overall X-ray variability pattern, the line islikely to arise from the relativistic region near the black hole.
label: human

text: We have been monitoring Supernova (SN) 1987A with {\it Chandra X-RayObservatory} since 1999. We present a review of previous results from our {\itChandra} observations, and some preliminary results from new {\it Chandra} dataobtained in 2006 and 2007. High resolution imaging and spectroscopic studies ofSN 1987A with {\it Chandra} reveal that X-ray emission of SN 1987A originatesfrom the hot gas heated by interaction of the blast wave with the ring-likedense circumstellar medium (CSM) that was produced by the massive progenitor'sequatorial stellar winds before the SN explosion. Our findings shed light on the dynamics and energetics of the exlposion, the intreaction of the supernova shcok with the surrounding medium, and the nature of the compact object in the remnant. At the age of 20 yr (as of 2007 January),X-ray luminosity of SN 1987A is $L_{\rm X}$ $\sim$ 2.4 $\times$ 10$^{36}$ ergss$^{-1}$ in the 0.5$-$10 keV band. X-ray emission is described by two-componentplane shock model with electron temperatures of $kT$ $\sim$ 0.3 and 2 keV. Asthe shock front interacts with dense CSM all around the inner ring, the X-rayremnant is now expanding at a much slower rate of $v$ $\sim$ 1400 km s$^{-1}$than it was until 2004 ($v$ $\sim$ 6000 km s$^{-1}$).
label: human

text: During the epoch of reionization, the formation of radiation sources isaccompanied by the growth of a H- photodissociating flux. We estimate theimpact of this flux on the formation of molecular hydrogen and cooling in thefirst galaxies, assuming different types of radiation sources (e.g. Pop II andPop III stars, miniquasars). Our findings demonstrate that the feedback from H- photodissociation induces significant alterations in the properties of baryonic gas, impacting the allocation of ionizing photons and influencing the timing and efficiency of cosmic reionization.
label: human

text: Elastic light scattering by mature red blood cells (RBCs) was theoreticallyand experimentally analyzed with the discrete dipole approximation (DDA) andthe scanning flow cytometry (SFC), respectively. SFC permits measurement ofangular dependence of light-scattering intensity (indicatrix) of singleparticles. A mature RBC is modeled as a biconcave disk in DDA simulations oflight scattering. We have studied the effect of RBC orientation related to thedirection of the incident light upon the indicatrix. Numerical calculations ofindicatrices for several aspect ratios and volumes of RBC have been carriedout. Comparison of the simulated indicatrices and indicatrices measured by SFCshowed good agreement, validating the biconcave disk model for a mature RBC.
