text: This article presents a thorough investigation into the periodic oscillation of an adiabatic piston, focusing on the rigorous mathematical results obtained through rigorous analysis and simulations. The adiabatic piston, which serves as a fundamental component in various thermodynamic systems, is subject to oscillatory behavior due to the energy exchange between the gas trapped inside the piston and its surroundings. Previous studies have provided qualitative descriptions of this phenomenon; however, a systematic framework to rigorously analyze and predict the period of oscillation has been lacking.The primary objective of this study is to establish a robust mathematical model that accurately characterizes the periodic oscillation of the adiabatic piston. By considering a comprehensive thermodynamic approach combined with the principles of classical mechanics, we derive a set of differential equations describing the dynamic behavior of the system. Utilizing advanced numerical methods, we simulate the system's behavior under different initial conditions and physical parameters, verifying the accuracy of our mathematical model.Through extensive computations and statistical analysis of the simulation results, we identify key factors that influence the period of oscillation. We alsoinvestigate the piston system when the particle interactions have beensmoothed. The convergence to the averaged behavior again takes place uniformly,both over initial conditions and over the amount of smoothing. The experimental results align closely with our mathematical model and simulation outcomes, further corroborating the accuracy and effectiveness of our approach.
label: llm

text: The phenomenon of gravitational waves (GWs) has opened up new avenues of exploration in astrophysics and cosmology. However, the propagation of GWs through space is not free from distortion effects. In this study, we investigate the distortion of GW packets due to their self-gravity, which arises from the gravitational interactions within the packet itself. Accounting for the wavedistortion would significantly decrease the waveform extraction errors innumerical simulations. Our analysis reveals that self-gravity can induce significant modifications in the shape and dynamics of GW packets, leading to observable changes in their waveforms and dispersion characteristics. We find that the magnitude of this distortion effect is dependent on the properties of the GW packet, such as its energy, frequency, and size. Understanding the impact of self-gravity on GW propagation is crucial for accurate interpretation of gravitational-wave observations and can provide further insights into the nature of gravity and the dynamics of astrophysical systems.
label: llm

text: Parity doubling, a phenomenon observed in particle physics, has attracted significant attention due to its implications for our understanding of fundamental interactions. This article provides a comprehensive review of parity doubling phenomena, focusing on its theoretical framework, experimental evidence, and potential implications. Theoretical descriptions of parity doubling involve the breaking of discrete symmetries in the underlying theories, leading to the doubling of particle states with opposite parity. This intriguing concept has been explored in various theoretical frameworks, including extensions of the Standard Model, supersymmetry, and string theory. Experimental evidence supporting parity doubling has been obtained through high-energy particle collisions and precision measurements. These experiments have revealed intriguing patterns of particle spectra and decay properties that are consistent with parity doubling predictions. We show the evolution ofvarious ideas about parity doubling. We begin with early approaches of 1960s(Regge theory and dynamical symmetries) and end up with the latest trends(manifestations of broader degeneracies and AdS/QCD). Furthermore, parity doubling could provide valuable insights into the nature of dark matter, the hierarchy problem, and the origin of the Universe's matter-antimatter asymmetry. This review also discusses ongoing research efforts to explore and test parity doubling predictions further. Experimental studies at particle accelerators, such as the Large Hadron Collider, and precision measurements in low-energy experiments hold great promise for advancing our knowledge of parity doubling and its relevance to particle physics. The experimental evidence for thisphenomenon is scrutinized in the non-strange sector.
label: llm

text: In recent years, the concept of cloaking has gained significant attention in the field of electromagnetic wave propagation. Full-wave electromagnetic cloaking, aiming to render objects invisible to incident waves, has been an intriguing and challenging subject of study. This article presents a rigorous time-domain analysis of full-wave electromagnetic cloaking and investigates its feasibility and limitations.The proposed analysis employs robust numerical simulations based on the finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) method. The FDTD method accurately captures the dynamics of electromagnetic fields and allows for a comprehensive examination of cloaking performance. Through extensive simulations, the effectiveness of various cloaking materials and geometries is evaluated. The results reveal that full-wave electromagnetic cloaking can indeed achieve remarkable levels of invisibility. Our results give a rigorous proof that theconstruction of \cite{glu1, glu2, le}, \cite{pss1} perfectly cloaks passive andactive devices from observation by electromagnetic waves. Using this fact, and since thecoordinate transformation is the identity outside of a ball, we prove that thescattering operator is the identity. The findings underscore the importance of considering the trade-offs between invisibility, material properties, and operational constraints when designing and implementing cloaking systems. Overall, this rigorous time-domain analysis contributes to the fundamental understanding and advancement of full-wave electromagnetic cloaking, paving the way for future research and exploration in this fascinating field.
label: llm

text: This study presents the measurement of the aerosol phase function at the Pierre Auger Observatory, which aims to better understand the scattering properties of atmospheric aerosols. The aerosol phase function describes the angular distribution of scattered light by aerosol particles, and it plays a crucial role in various atmospheric and climate studies. The measurement was conducted using a combination of ground-based lidar and sunphotometer observations, providing a comprehensive dataset of aerosol scattering characteristics. This paper describes thedesign, current status, standard operation procedure, and performance of theAPF system at the Pierre Auger Observatory. The observed aerosol phase functions were compared to existing models and exhibited deviations, emphasizing the importance of regional measurements for accurate aerosol characterization. The findings of this study contribute to improving our understanding of the impact of aerosols on Earth's radiation budget and climate system, facilitating more accurate radiative transfer simulations and climate models.
label: llm

text: This article presents a comprehensive census of the IC 348 nebula using data obtained from the Spitzer Space Telescope. The IC 348 nebula, located in the constellation Perseus, is a site of active star formation and offers a unique opportunity to study the early stages of stellar evolution. Our study aims to provide a detailed inventory of the young stellar objects (YSOs) within the nebula and investigate their physical properties.To achieve this, we utilize the Infrared Array Camera (IRAC) and the Multiband Imaging Photometer for Spitzer (MIPS) instruments on board the Spitzer Space Telescope. We analyze the infrared excess emission from sources in the IC 348 region, a signature of YSOs, and identify a total of 150 YSO candidates. The YSOs are classified into different evolutionary stages based on their spectral energy distributions and spatial distribution within the nebula.We investigate the physical characteristics of the identified YSOs, such as their luminosities, effective temperatures, and masses. We show thatthe IC 348 cluster is of order 3-5 crossing times old, and, as evidenced by itssmooth radial profile and confirmed mass segregation, is likely relaxed. Whileit seems apparent that the current cluster configuration is the result ofdynamical evolution and its primordial structure has been erased, our findingssupport a model where embedded clusters are built up from numerous smallersub-clusters. By assessing the disk properties, such as disk fraction and disk masses, we gain insights into the disk evolution and its connection to the star formation processes in the IC 348 nebula.Our findings contribute to the understanding of the star formation activity within the IC 348 nebula and provide valuable constraints for theoretical models of early stellar evolution.
label: llm

text: Parametric learning and Monte Carlo optimization are two essential techniques in machine learning and optimization research. This article explores the integration of these two approaches to enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of learning and optimization processes. The parametric learning framework provides a powerful foundation for modeling complex systems by defining a set of parameters that govern the system's behavior. However, traditional parametric learning methods often suffer from high computational costs and convergence issues when applied to large-scale problems. In contrast, Monte Carlo optimization leverages random sampling to explore the solution space and estimate the objective function. This stochastic approach enables the identification of promising regions in the search space, but it may suffer from convergence limitations and lack of accuracy.By combining parametric learning with Monte Carlo optimization, we propose a novel approach that addresses the limitations of each technique. Accordingly, by combining these first twocontributions, we can apply all PL techniques to BO. Immediate sampling transforms the original BOproblem into an MCO problem. We investigate the impact of different parametric learning models, Monte Carlo sampling strategies, and convergence criteria on the overall performance.
label: llm

text: This paper introduces a novel approach for prediction modeling, called the Spline Single-Index Prediction Model (SSIPM). The SSIPM is designed to handle complex relationships between predictor variables and the response variable by incorporating spline functions and a single-index structure. The use of spline functions allows for flexible modeling of nonlinear relationships, while the single-index structure reduces dimensionality and enhances interpretability. The SSIPM is built on the foundation of semiparametric regression and employs penalized likelihood estimation to achieve efficient model fitting. The proposed model is evaluated using simulated data and real-world datasets from various domains, including finance and healthcare. An iterative optimization routine is used which issufficiently fast for the user to analyze large data of high dimension withinseconds. A polynomial spline estimator is proposed forthe single-index prediction coefficients, and is shown to be root-n consistentand asymptotically normal. Overall, the SSIPM presents a powerful and flexible tool for prediction modeling, offering a balance between interpretability and accuracy in complex data analysis tasks.
label: llm

text: This study presents a novel approach to estimate experimental data redundancy and provides related statistical measures. Redundancy is a crucial aspect in designing efficient experiments and optimizing resources in scientific research. By accurately assessing the amount of redundancy present in experimental data, researchers can make informed decisions regarding the need for additional measurements or the removal of redundant data points. The performance of the approximate estimation of these statistics isdemonstrated on two-dimensional normally distributed random data. The statistical measures generated include redundancy ratio, redundancy index, and redundancy factor, which offer quantitative indicators of the extent of redundancy in the experimental data. The effectiveness of the approach is demonstrated through a series of simulated experiments and real-world case studies, highlighting its utility in various scientific domains. The estimation of experimental data redundancy and the associated statistical measures provided by this research contribute to enhancing experimental design, improving data quality, and optimizing research resources.
label: llm

text: We investigate the phenomenon of entanglement increase resulting from local interactions involving not-completely-positive (NCP) maps. By considering a system of two qubits coupled to individual environments, we demonstrate that under certain conditions, NCP maps can drive the generation of entanglement between the qubits. We analyze the dynamics of the system and provide explicit examples of NCP maps that lead to entanglement increase. Similar changes for the twoqubits are made with a swap operation between one of the qubits and a control;then there are compensating changes of entanglement that involve the control.When the entanglement increases, the map that describes the change of the stateof the two entangled qubits is not completely positive. Our findings highlight the potential of NCP maps as a resource for enhancing entanglement in quantum systems, suggesting novel avenues for manipulating and harnessing entanglement in practical applications of quantum information processing.
label: llm

text: Dislocation dynamics plays a fundamental role in understanding plastic deformation in crystalline materials. In this study, we investigate the Peierls-Nabarro relief, which describes the structural defects known as dislocations and their movement within the crystal lattice. We develop a comprehensive model that incorporates temperature and strain rate dependencies to accurately capture the behavior of body-centered cubic metals. By considering the Peierls barrier as a periodic function dependent on shear stresses, we extract its shape and explore its relationship to applied loading conditions. Utilizing atomistic simulations, we determine the minimum energy path between potential minima, allowing us to quantify the corresponding activation barrier. Notably, our model successfully reproduces the well-known twinning-antitwinning asymmetry and accounts for the effects of both parallel and perpendicular shear stresses. The behavior of the flow stress at the range of athermicanomalies is modeled by changing the mechanism of the dislocation motion fromthe thermally activated hopping over the barriers to the quantum tunnellingthrough them. The theory of quantum mechanical dislocationtunnelling through the Peierls-Nabarro barriers is extended and compared withexperimental data on the plasticity of alkali halides, BCC and HCP metals atlow temperatures. Our results pave the way for comparing theoretical predictions with experimental observations, enriching our understanding of dislocation motion and plasticity in metallic systems.
label: llm

text: In this article, we explore the interplay between Landau-Lifshitz sigma-models, fermions, and the AdS/CFT correspondence. We begin by introducing the Landau-Lifshitz sigma-model and studying its properties as a non-relativistic field theory. We show that the sigma-model in the presence of fermions exhibits interesting dynamical behaviors, including the emergence of non-trivial ground states and topological excitations.Next, we investigate the connection between the Landau-Lifshitz sigma-model and the AdS/CFT correspondence. By considering a decoupling limit, we establish a correspondence between the Landau-Lifshitz sigma-model with fermions and a string theory in anti-de Sitter space coupled to a conformal field theory. Intriguingly, this correspondence reveals that the Landau-Lifshitz sigma-model captures aspects of both the bulk and boundary theories.Furthermore, we analyze the spectrum of excitations in the Landau-Lifshitz sigma-model and identify the corresponding states in the string theory. Remarkably, we find a precise matching between the energy spectra of the two theories, providing strong evidence for the validity of the AdS/CFT correspondence in this context.Moreover, we investigate the effects of quantum corrections in both the Landau-Lifshitz sigma-model and the string theory. In the context of the large spin limit of theAdS/CFT correspondence, we map the Lagrangians of these sub-sectors tocorresponding truncations of the $PSU(2,2|4)/PS(U(2|2)^2)$ Landau-Lifshitzsigma-model. This sigma model describes the thermodynamic limitof the spin-chain Hamiltonian obtained from the complete one-loop dilatationoperator of the N=4 super Yang-Mills (SYM) theory. We highlight the relevance of Landau-Lifshitz sigma-models with fermions as a valuable tool for studying non-relativistic quantum field theories and their dual string theory descriptions.
label: llm

text: In this study, we present the results of near-infrared spectroscopic observations of the moons Ariel, Umbriel, Titania, and Oberon, obtained using the Infrared Telescope Facility (IRTF) and the SpeX instrument. Our main objective is to investigate the distributions of H2O and CO2 ices on the surfaces of these four Uranian moons. By analyzing the absorption features in the 1.0 to 2.5 micron range, we have identified the presence of H2O and CO2 ices on all four moons. Furthermore, we have examined the spatial variations in the ice abundances across the surfaces of these moons. Our results indicate that H2O ice is more abundant than CO2 ice, and both ices exhibit variations in their distributions, suggesting potential geological and/or environmental influences. We use the CO2 absorptionsto map the longitudinal distribution of CO2 ice on Ariel, Umbriel, and Titania,showing that it is most abundant on their trailing hemispheres. No CO2 absorption is seen inOberon spectra, and the strengths of the CO2 ice bands decline withplanetocentric distance from Ariel through Titania. Further investigations combining spectroscopic observations with other complementary data and theoretical models are necessary to uncover the complex interplay of processes shaping the surface ices on Ariel, Umbriel, Titania, and Oberon.
label: llm

text: We present a study on the mid-infrared fine structure line ratios in active galactic nuclei (AGNs) based on observations conducted with the Spitzer Infrared Spectrograph (IRS). Our analysis focuses on examining the evidence for extinction by the torus, a central component in AGN models. We analyze a sample of AGNs and investigate the line ratios of [NeII](12.8) to [NeIII](15.6) and [OIV](25.9) to [NeII](12.8), which are sensitive to the presence of dust and extinction effects. Our results reveal a clear trend of decreasing line ratios with increasing AGN obscuration, suggesting that the torus indeed contributes significantly to the extinction in the mid-infrared regime. By comparing the observed line ratios with theoretical predictions from photoionization models, we confirm that the dust within the torus is capable of absorbing and scattering the mid-infrared emission, leading to a suppression of the fine structure lines. Because the temperature of the gas, the amount ofextinction, and the effect of absorption and stimulated emission on the lineratios are all unknown, we are not able to determine the electron densitiesassociated with the [NeV] line flux ratios for the objects in our sample. We argue thatdifferential infrared extinction to the [NeV] emitting region due to dust inthe obscuring torus is responsible for the ratios below the low density limitand we suggest that the ratio may be a tracer of the inclination angle of thetorus to our line of sight. Our results contribute to a better understanding of the dust distribution and extinction processes in AGNs, shedding light on their intricate structures and the interplay between central engines and surrounding environments.
label: llm

text: We present a study on a very massive runaway star originating from Cygnus OB2, an intriguing region known for its rich population of early-type stars. Through a combination of observational data and analysis, we aimed to uncover the unique properties and dynamics of this particular runaway star. Our investigation involved the utilization of various techniques, including near-infrared color-color diagrams and spectroscopic analysis. We identified a significant number of early-type stars within the targeted region, amounting to approximately half of the observed sample. Notably, we discovered an extended halo of early-type stars surrounding Cygnus OB2, potentially shedding light on its formation and relationship with other nearby associations. The presence of evolved massive stars exhibiting Brackett emission lines further added to the complexity of this region. Arunaway formation mechanism by means of dynamical ejection is consistent withour results. The high spatial resolution of the MSXobservations allows us to determine its direction of motion in the plane of thesky by means of the symmetry axis of the well-defined bow shock, which matcheswell the orientation expected from the proper motion. The comprehensive understanding of this very massive runaway star and its connection to Cygnus OB2 contributes to our knowledge of massive star formation and interaction with their surrounding environments.
label: llm

text: Protoplanetary disks play a crucial role in the formation of planetary systems, and the presence of magnetic fields within these disks can significantly impact their evolution. In this study, we investigate the characteristics and effects of magnetic fields in protoplanetary disks. We consider different scenarios, including the presence of dust grains and their influence on the magnetorotational instability (MRI). Our analysis reveals that when no grains or grains larger than 1 micron are present, the magnetic field is well coupled to the gas in the midplane. However, the introduction of small grains (0.1 micron) results in reduced magnetic activity and limited coupling between the field and the fluid. We find that Ohmic diffusion dominates at certain radii, while ambipolar diffusion becomes severe at larger distances, hindering magnetic coupling throughout the disk. However, once grains havegrown to a few microns in size their effect starts to wane and magnetic fieldscan begin to couple to the gas even at the disk midplane. Because ions aregenerally decoupled from the magnetic field by neutral collisions whileelectrons are not, the Hall effect tends to dominate the diffusion of themagnetic field when it is able to partially couple to the gas. Despite these effects, MRI modes still exhibit growth over a wide range of magnetic field strengths, with Hall diffusion playing a crucial role in the inner regions of the disk.Overall, our results suggest that the magnetic field can maintain coupling with the gas and exhibit shear even when small dust grains are mixed with the gas in protoplanetary disks. While the magnetic coupling is reduced, it is still influential in driving fluid motion. The presence of dust grains alters the properties of perturbations and the range of magnetic field strengths for which MRI-unstable modes exist. They have the potential to efficiently transport angularmomentum by MHD turbulence or via the magnetocentrifugal acceleration ofoutflows from the disk surface, and magnetically-driven mixing has implicationsfor disk chemistry and evolution of the grain population.
label: llm

text: We investigate the evolution of galaxies in the infrared (IR) regime by comparing the predictions of a hierarchical galaxy formation model with observational data from the SPITZER telescope. The model employed in this study incorporates a semi-analytical approach to galaxy formation and evolution. We focus on the properties of galaxies in the IR wavelengths, which are influenced by the presence of interstellar dust and its effect on the spectral energy distribution (SED). By comparing the model predictions with SPITZER data, we aim to assess the model's ability to reproduce key observables.To generate synthetic SEDs, we combine the semi-analytical model with a radiative transfer code, GRASIL, which accurately accounts for the effects of dust on starlight absorption and thermal emission. We extract star formation history samples from the model and compute synthetic SEDs spanning the near- to far-infrared wavelengths at different redshift ranges. We compare the model with observational data from the SPITZERSpace Telescope, with the model parameters fixed at values chosen beforeSPITZER data became available. We have shown previously thatthe top-heavy IMF seems to be necessary to explain the number counts of faintsub-mm galaxies. Notably, there are discrepancies observed in regions dominated by polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) emission and at sub-millimeter wavelengths, suggesting potential limitations or differences between the radiative transfer approach and other IR flux estimators.By quantifying the discrepancies and identifying critical issues, our study contributes to a better understanding of the accuracy and reliability of semi-analytical models in reproducing the observed IR properties of galaxies.
label: llm

text: Stochastic resonance, a phenomenon observed in a variety of complex systems, involves the amplification of weak signals in the presence of noise. In this study, we investigate aspects of stochastic resonance in reaction-diffusion systems using the nonequilibrium-potential approach. By considering the interplay between nonlinear reaction kinetics and diffusive processes, we demonstrate the emergence of stochastic resonance in such systems. Specifically, we analyze the response of the reaction-diffusion system to weak periodic forcing and examine the conditions under which stochastic resonance occurs. Our results reveal that the presence of noise can enhance the system's sensitivity to weak signals, leading to a resonant amplification of the signal. Afterdiscussing for this system the second aspect enumerated above, we derive fromit -through an adiabatic-like elimination of the inhibitor field- an effectivescalar model that includes a nonlocal contribution. A yet lesstrivial generalization is exemplified by a stylized version of theFitzHugh-Nagumo system, a paradigm of the activator-inhibitor class. Overall, our study provides new insights into the rich behavior of stochastic resonance in complex reaction-diffusion systems, highlighting the importance of noise in modulating their dynamical responses.
label: llm

text: Abstract:In this study, we present a comprehensive analysis of the luminous infrared composite Seyfert 2 galaxy NGC 7679, focusing particularly on its properties as revealed through the emission line of [O III] 5007. Utilizing high-resolution spectroscopic observations obtained from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) and optical imaging data, we investigate the kinematic and physical characteristics of the galaxy. Our analysis reveals the presence of a complex emission line region displaying extended and asymmetric structures. We employ line diagnostics to estimate the oxygen abundances and infer the excitation mechanisms responsible for the observed emission. Moreover, we perform detailed measurements of the line fluxes and widths, enabling us to assess the strength and nature of the active galactic nucleus (AGN) in NGC 7679. The results indicate significant deviations from typical Seyfert 2 galaxies, suggesting the presence of enhanced emission associated with an obscured AGN. The maximum ofionization by the AGN power-law continuum traced by [O III] 5007/Halpha ratiois displaced by ~ 13 arcsec eastward from the nucleus. The [OIII] 5007 image of the NGC 7679 shows elliptical isophotes extended along thePA ~ 80 deg in the direction to the counterpart galaxy NGC 7682. Our study sheds light on the complex interplay between AGN activity, star formation, and the host galaxy properties in luminous infrared Seyfert 2 galaxies, contributing to a deeper understanding of the evolution of active galaxies.
label: llm

text: Abstract:In this paper, we investigate the application of the first law of thermodynamics to Black Holes in the context of Boosted Kaluza-Klein (BKK) spacetimes. Building upon previous studies on BKK black holes, we derive and analyze the first law by considering the variation of the mass, angular momentum, electric charge, and boost parameters of BKK black holes. We employ the framework of the isolated horizon formalism and incorporate the effects of the extended phasespace thermodynamics. Finally, we show that the `tension first law' derived byTraschen and Fox in the static case has the form of a thermodynamic Gibbs-Duhemrelation and give its extension in the stationary, non-rotating case. Utilizing the mathematical formalism of Einstein-Gauss-Bonnet gravity and f(R) gravity theories, we quantify the impact of the boost parameters on the thermodynamic quantities of BKK black holes. Our findings reveal intriguing insights into the thermodynamic behavior and holographic aspects of Boosted Kaluza-Klein black holes and provide a foundation for further research in this field.
label: llm

text: Abstract:In this study, we investigate the self-organization of metal nanostructures through laser-driven thermocapillary convection. By employing a combination of experimental observations and theoretical modeling, we explore the mechanisms and dynamics involved in the formation and evolution of metal nanostructures under localized laser heating. Through high-resolution microscopy studies, we observe the emergence of intricate spatial patterns and morphologies driven by the interplay between thermal gradients, surface tension, and fluid flow. For h_{0}\leq2 nm, ahydrodynamic instability of a spinodally unstable film leads to the formationof nanoparticles. Our findings provide valuable insights into the fundamental mechanisms governing self-organization in metal nanostructures and pave the way for the controlled fabrication of complex functional materials at the nanoscale using laser-induced thermocapillary effects.
label: llm

text: Abstract:In this study, we investigate the oriented growth of pentacene films on vacuum-deposited polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) layers that are aligned using the rubbing technique. By employing X-ray diffraction (XRD) and atomic force microscopy (AFM), we characterize the crystallographic orientation and morphological properties of the pentacene films. Our results reveal that the rubbing technique applied to the PTFE surface leads to a preferred orientation of the pentacene crystals, with the (001) plane parallel to the rubbing direction. Furthermore, we find that the rubbing speed and pressure significantly influence the degree of orientation and the surface roughness of the pentacene films. Analysis of the angular-dependent XRD patterns indicates a preferential alignment of the molecular long axis along the rubbing direction. Using the coldfriction technique orienting PTFE layers with unidirectional grooves areobtained. By means ofellipsometry, values of refractive index between 1.33 and 1.36 have beenobtained for PTFE films in dependence on deposition conditions. These results provide valuable insights into the control of molecular orientation and its effect on device performance in organic electronics applications.

text: Abstract:This research investigates the presence and characteristics of smooth and starburst tidal tails within the GEMS (Galaxy Evolution from Morphologies and SEDs) and GOODS (Great Observatories Origins Deep Survey) fields. By combining deep imaging data obtained from the Hubble Space Telescope with advanced data analysis techniques, we identify and analyze a diverse sample of tidal tails associated with interacting galaxies in these fields. Our findings reveal the coexistence of both smooth and starburst tidal tails, providing valuable insights into the dynamical processes involved in galaxy interactions. The smooth tidal tails exhibit a more gradual and elongated morphology, suggesting a prolonged interaction and gravitational stripping from a previous encounter. On the other hand, the starburst tidal tails present a more irregular and clumpy structure, indicative of rapid star formation triggered by gravitational perturbations. We investigate the redshift distribution and properties of the host galaxies in relation to the tidal tails, revealing a correlation between higher redshift and the presence of starburst tidal tails. Mosttidal dwarfs are blue and probably form by gravitational instabilities in thegas. One exception has a5x10**9 Msun smooth red clump that could be a pure stellar condensation. The identification and characterization of smooth and starburst tidal tails in the GEMS and GOODS fields contribute to our understanding of the complex mechanisms involved in the growth and transformation of galaxies over cosmic time.
label: llm

text: Abstract:In this study, we investigate the properties of quantum and classical spins on a spatially distorted Kagome lattice, focusing on their relevance to the mineral compound Volborthite. By employing a combination of theoretical modeling and numerical simulations, we explore the intricate interplay between spatial distortions and spin interactions in this unique lattice structure. Our analysis involves both quantum and classical spin models, allowing us to examine the distinct behaviors exhibited by these two frameworks. We begin by constructing a theoretical framework based on the Heisenberg model, which captures the quantum nature of spins and their interactions on the distorted Kagome lattice. Using advanced techniques such as Dzyaloshinsky-Moriya interactions and post-Newtonian order calculations, we elucidate the influence of geometric distortions on the spin dynamics. This isconfirmed by a large-N approximation on the O($n$) model on this lattice. Whilethe saddle point solution produces a line degeneracy, $O(1/n)$ correctionsselect the non-trivial wavevector of the striped chirality state. The quantum nature of spins manifests in the form of spin liquid behavior and fractionalized excitations, whereas classical spins exhibit a rich variety of ordered and disordered magnetic phases.
label: llm

text: Abstract:This study focuses on the effects of light unsaturated hydrocarbon dopants, specifically allene and propyne, on the characteristics of rich methane premixed laminar flames. A comprehensive experimental investigation was conducted to analyze various flame properties, including flame structure, laminar burning velocity, and flame stability. The experiments were carried out under controlled conditions using a counterflow twin-flame configuration coupled with advanced diagnostics techniques.The results revealed significant alterations in the flame structure and burning characteristics when allene and propyne were added as dopants to the methane-air mixture. The temperature was measured using aPtRh (6%)-PtRh (30%) thermocouple settled inside the enclosure and ranged from700 K close to the burner up to 1850 K. In order to model these new results,some improvements have been made to a mechanism previously developed in ourlaboratory for the reactions of C3-C4 unsaturated hydrocarbons. Additionally, the addition of allene and propyne caused changes in the reaction pathways and species profiles within the flame zone, as confirmed by species concentration measurements.Furthermore, the influence of dopant concentration on flame stability and extinction limits was investigated. It was observed that increasing the concentration of allene and propyne resulted in a substantial increase in flame extinction strain rate, indicating enhanced flame resistance to quenching.These findings provide valuable insights into the impact of light unsaturated hydrocarbon dopants, such as allene and propyne, on the behavior and characteristics of methane flames. Understanding these effects is crucial for optimizing the performance and efficiency of practical combustion systems and contributing to the development of cleaner and more sustainable energy technologies.

text: Abstract:In this research article, we investigate the performance of sparse estimators and explore their compatibility with the oracle property, with a particular focus on Hodges' estimator. By applying convex optimization techniques and utilizing results from density-matrix-functional theory, we establish the theoretical foundations for understanding the behavior of these estimators in high-dimensional settings. Through rigorous mathematical investigations and analytical proofs, we demonstrate that Hodges' estimator exhibits desirable properties such as risk minimization and asymptotic consistency. We find that this estimator can perform ratherpoorly in finite samples and that its worst-case performance relative tomaximum likelihood deteriorates with increasing sample size when the estimatoris tuned to sparsity. Furthermore, we provide empirical evidence supported by simulations and real-world datasets to validate the theoretical predictions, thereby highlighting the practical significance of sparse estimators in various domains. Overall, this study sheds light on the renewed importance of Hodges' estimator and its applicability in contemporary statistical inference, emphasizing the potential for enhanced estimation accuracy and risk assessment in complex data analysis tasks.

text: Abstract:In this paper, we study the number of moduli associated with irreducible families of plane curves that possess nodes and cusps. By employing algebraic geometry techniques, we investigate the intricate relationships between the topological properties of these curves and the moduli spaces they belong to. Our analysis reveals that the number of moduli is closely correlated with the type and distribution of singularities present on the curves. In this paper we constructexamples of families of irreducible plane curves with nodes and cusps assingularities having expected number of moduli and with non-positiveBrill-Noether number.

text: This study examines the phenomenon of spontaneous Lorentz violation within the framework of non-Abelian gauge fields. We present a novel mechanism whereby non-Abelian gauge fields can exhibit characteristics of pseudo-Goldstone vector bosons, resulting in the emergence of spontaneous Lorentz symmetry breaking. The theoretical foundations of non-Abelian gauge fields and their connection to symmetry breaking patterns are discussed, highlighting the acquisition of pseudo-Goldstone boson nature through specific choices of the gauge group and Higgs potential, akin to the Higgs mechanism. Moreover, we analyze the implications of this Lorentz violation in particle physics and cosmology. We investigate the modifications to the dispersion relation and the resulting particle properties for the pseudo-Goldstone vector bosons. Remarkably, they remainstrictly massless, being protected by gauge invariance of the Yang-Mills theoryinvolved. As a result, while the pure Lorentz violation still generates only onegenuine Goldstone vector boson, the accompanying pseudo-Goldstone vector bosonsrelated to the $SO(D,3D)$ breaking also come into play in the final arrangementof the entire Goldstone vector field multiplet. The proposed mechanism opens up new avenues for further theoretical and experimental investigations, providing a unique perspective on the intricate interplay between gauge fields and spontaneous symmetry breaking.

text: This paper presents a thorough investigation into the quantitative size-dependent structure and strain analysis of CdSe nanoparticles using atomic pair distribution function (PDF) analysis. The analysis revealed significant size-dependent modifications in the atomic structure of CdSe nanoparticles, including distortions in bond length and variations in strain. Furthermore, the strain analysis offered valuable insights into the lattice distortion induced by nanoparticle size. The outcomes underscore the importance of atomic-scale structural characterization in comprehending the properties and performance of CdSe nanoparticles, thereby facilitating their design and application in diverse nanotechnology fields.

text: This academic article investigates the transient behavior of surface plasmon polaritons (SPPs) upon scattering at a subwavelength groove. text: This article investigates the strong spherical asymptotics of the Rotor-Router Aggregation (RRA) process and the Divisible Sandpile (DSP) model. We derive explicit expressions for the scaling exponents that govern the growth of the aggregate's size and shape in both models. Similar bounds apply in higher dimensions. Specifically, we observe that the aggregate's surface area grows asymptotically following a power law of time, with the scaling exponents determined by the specific model parameters. Additionally, we identify critical thresholds in both RRA and DSP, which mark the transition between different growth regimes.To validate our theoretical findings, we conduct numerical simulations that demonstrate the applicability of our results. The obtained strong spherical asymptotics offer valuable insights into the long-term behavior of particle aggregation and sandpile growth processes, contributing to the understanding of complex systems evolving on lattices.In summary, this article presents a comprehensive study of the RRA and DSP models, providing a deeper understanding of their asymptotic properties and shedding light on the universal aspects of particle aggregation and sandpile growth in two dimensions.

text: This article presents the findings derived from Hubble Space Telescope (HST) observations employing the Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) coronagraph to investigate the dust environment surrounding the young stellar object HD 100546. Our observations unveil a complex and intricate distribution of dust features, including multiple spiral arms, clumps, and gaps. Our results reveal variations in both the size and density of the dust grains across different regions of the disk. Furthermore, a pronounced cavity within the disk has been identified, potentially stemming from interactions with nascent planets or other external mechanisms.Moreover, we have investigated the spectral energy distribution (SED) of HD 100546 through multi-wavelength photometry. Along the majordisk axis, the colors of the scattered-light relative to the star are \Delta(F435W-F606W) ~ 0.0--0.2 mags and \Delta (F435W-F814W)~0.5--1 mags. The inter-arm space becomes brighter, but the structures become moreneutral in color at longer wavelengths, which is not consistent with modelsthat assume that they are due to the effects of a warped disk. Our results corroborate the hypothesis of ongoing planetesimal formation triggered by gravitational instability or the accumulation of dust grains.

text: This article investigates the thermodynamic properties of boosted Kaluza-Klein black holes within the framework of the first law of thermodynamics. We examine a higher-dimensional spacetime scenario with a small, compactified extra dimension, which allows for the existence of Kaluza-Klein modes. By utilizing the boosted Kerr-Schild ansatz, we derive a mass-energy formula for the black hole, incorporating both the conventional Schwarzschild term and an additional contribution from the boost. Finally, we show that the `tension first law' derived byTraschen and Fox in the static case has the form of a thermodynamic Gibbs-Duhemrelation and give its extension in the stationary, non-rotating case. Our findings demonstrate that the first law of thermodynamics holds for boosted Kaluza-Klein black holes, affirming the conservation of energy and the correspondence between variations in mass-energy and changes in other thermodynamic parameters. Overall, this study enhances our understanding of the thermodynamic behavior of black holes in higher-dimensional spacetimes, while shedding light on the interplay between boost effects and the Kaluza-Klein mechanism.

text: This study presents the results of spectroscopy conducted on three giant Lyman-alpha (Ly-alpha) nebulae associated with radio galaxies at a redshift of approximately z~2.5. The aim of this research was to investigate the physical properties, kinematics, and origins of these enigmatic Ly-alpha nebulae, which are known to be massive and extended structures in the distant universe.The three Ly-alpha nebulae were observed using the VIsible MultiObject Spectrograph (VIMOS) instrument on the Very Large Telescope (VLT), allowing for high-resolution spectra to be captured over a wide field of view. By employing both long-slit spectroscopy and integral field spectroscopy techniques, detailed information was obtained regarding the spatial distribution of Ly-alpha emission, velocity dispersion, and line profiles across the nebulae.The analysis revealed complex structures within each Ly-alpha nebula, including multiple peaks, filaments, and extended regions of emission. This adds further support to our previous conclusion that the_quiescent_ giant nebulae associated with this and other high redshift powerfulradio galaxies are in infall. These observations suggest that the Ly-alpha nebulae are likely powered by a combination of active galactic nucleus (AGN) feedback, galactic-scale winds, and star formation activity.Furthermore, the Ly-alpha nebulae exhibit spatially correlated Ly-alpha and [O III] emission, suggesting a connection between the ionized gas traced by Ly-alpha and the AGN activity traced by [O III] emission. Additionally, Ly-alpha emission was detected beyond the boundaries of the radio galaxy hosting the AGN, providing support for the idea that Ly-alpha nebulae can span sizes of hundreds of kiloparsecs.In summary, this study's findings offer valuable insights into the nature and origins of giant Ly-alpha nebulae associated with z~2.5 radio galaxies.

text: This academic article investigates the phenomenon of a deformed Wigner crystal in a one-dimensional quantum dot. The main objective of the study is to explore the structural and electronic properties of a Wigner crystal confined to one dimension, achieved through a potential well structure. Numerical simulations based on density functional theory are employed by the authors to unravel the intricate interplay between electron-electron interactions and confinement effects.The results demonstrate that the one-dimensional Wigner crystal exhibits a distinctive deformed structure due to the strong correlation effects. The deformation arises from the interplay between the confinement potential and the repulsive electron-electron interactions, resulting in a distortion of the crystal lattice. The analysis of the electronic properties of the deformed Wigner crystal reveals intriguing features, including energy gaps and localized electronic states within the crystal structure.Moreover, this article investigates the impact of various parameters, such as dot size and electron density, on the deformation and electronic properties of the Wigner crystal. An improvement of theLuttinger liquid model is proposed which allows one to describe the abovefeatures correctly. It is based on the corrected form of the density operatorconserving the particle number. The insights gleaned from this research enhance our understanding of exotic electronic phenomena in quantum dots and open up possibilities for potential applications in nanoscale devices and quantum computing.

text: The Crab pusar, located at the centr of the Crab Nebula, is a well-known astrophysical object that emits periodic pulses of electromagnetic radiation. text: Thifs article presents the results of multiband Nbservations of the blazar PKS2155-304 carried out in 2005 using near-infrared (NIR) and optical wavelengths. text: The phenomenon known as the transverse proximity reverberations has been studied drastically in astrophysics, particularly regarding its impact on spectral hardness along the line of sight towards distant objects. text: Decoherence and relaxation treating play a pivotal role in the study of quantum systems interacting with fluctuating environments. The captains equation is derived using the quantum Langevin equation, which accounts for both the deterministic and stochastic potent arising from the system-environment interaction. Next, we discussed the consequences of the fluctuating periphery on the decoherence timescale and relaxation dynamics of the quantum system. Inaddition, we found that our model predicts localization of the qubit in thestrong-coupling regime, resembling that of the spin-boson model. text: This literature presents a systematic scan conducted to explore 7-colourings of the grid and investigate their properties. We detect no significant molecular gas or dust emission within the cluster's vicinity. The neutral gas distribution shows a marked gradient along the cluster's eastern edge, likely due to the presence of a nearby molecular cloud. The cluster's stellar population is found to be well-established, with a ages of 1-10 Myr. Additionally we re-calculatedthe kinematic distances to nearby HII regions and supernova remnants based onour new Galaxic rotation curve. We also report on small expanding HI features around thecluster with a maximum dynamic age of 600,000 years and a larger bubble whichhas a minimum dynamic age of 2.5 million years. Our results contribute to a greater understanding of the structure and evolution of massive stellar clusters.

text: In this article, we explore the concept of exact fuzzy sphere thermodynamics in the context of matrix quantum mechanics. We begin by introducing the fundamental principles of matrix quantum mechanics and its connection to fuzzy spheres. We then delve into the thermodynamic properties of fuzzy spheres, specifically examining the entropy and internal energy of these systems. In the region below the criticalpoint, which is not accessible by perturbation theory, we observe the Hagedorntransition. Our results provide valuable insights into the behavior of fuzzy spheres at the quantum level, and have important implications for the study of quantum thermodynamics. We conclude by discussing the potential applications of our findings in various fields, including quantum information theory and condensed matter physics.

text: This article discusses the concept of self-consistency in hadron physics and its significance in understanding the strong nuclear force. The authors argue that self-consistency is a crucial aspect of theoretical models in hadron physics, as it allows for a more accurate and reliable prediction of experimental results. They demonstrate how self-consistency can be applied to various hadronic processes, such as meson-nucleon scattering and meson decay. The relevance of exotic baryonresonances for the spectral distortion of the $D_s^\pm$ in nuclear matter ispointed out. They propose a novel approach that combines theoretical models with machine learning algorithms to improve the accuracy of predictions. The article concludes by highlighting the importance of self-consistency in advancing our understanding of the strong nuclear force and its applications in various fields, including nuclear physics, astrophysics, and cosmology.

text: In this study, we present the results of multidimensional supernova simulations that incorporate approximative neutrino transport and focus on the role of convection and the advective-acoustic cycle in the supernova core. Our simulations reveal that convection plays a crucial role in the evolution of the supernova, with the formation of large-scale circulating flows that have a significant impact on the hydrodynamics and energetics of the explosion. We find that the advective-acoustic cycle, which involves the interaction between fluid advection and acoustic waves, is an important mechanism for energy transport in the supernova core. A rapidly contracting andmore compact nascent NS turns out to be favorable for explosions, because theaccretion luminosity and neutrino heating are larger and the growth rate of theSASI is higher. Additionally, we find that the multidimensional nature of the simulations allows for a more accurate representation of the complex physics involved in supernovae, leading to improved predictions for observational signatures. Overall, our study highlights the importance of considering multidimensional effects and approximative neutrino transport in supernova simulations in order to better understand these powerful astrophysical events.
label: llm

text: In this study, we utilize the Ostriker-Vishniac effect to investigate high redshift galaxy clusters through gravitational lensing. The Ostriker-Vishniac effect refers to the amplification of cosmic microwave background radiation (CMB) temperature fluctuations caused by the Sunyaev-Zel'dovich (SZ) effect. By analyzing the CMB temperature fluctuations, we are able to detect and characterize high redshift galaxy clusters that would otherwise be beyond the reach of current telescopes. After designing an optimal filter for this particular lensing signalwe explore the signal-to-noise ratio for different scenarios varying theresolution of the experiment, its sensitivity, and the level of contaminationdue to point sources. This technique offers a promising avenue for exploring the most distant regions of the cosmos, allowing us to gain a deeper understanding of the universe's origins and history.
label: llm

text: The GRO 1008-57 system has long been a subject of interest due to its unique circumstellar disk. However, new observations reveal that the disk is not always present, leaving astronomers puzzled. This study examines the phenomenon of the disappearing disk and explores possible explanations for its presence and absence. Furthermore, the shape of the emission linepermits a direct determination of the disk size which is in good agreement withtheoretical estimates. Our results have important implications for our understanding of disk evolution and the formation of exoplanets.
label: llm

text: This study aimed to extract galactic binary signals from the first round of Mock LISA Data Challenges, a simulated dataset designed to mimic the expected data from the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA) mission. We developed a custom pipeline using machine learning algorithms to identify and characterize galactic binary signals in the data. Our analysis revealed several promising candidates, including a few with high signal-to-noise ratios. Theonly misses were later traced to a coding error that affected high frequencysources. The results of this study demonstrate the potential of machine learning algorithms for identifying galactic binary signals in LISA data and pave the way for further exploration of the galaxy using this technique.

text: GRB 060912A is a gamma-ray burst (GRB) that has been widely studied due to its unique properties, which challenge our understanding of the traditional long-short GRB divide. The burst was initially classified as a long GRB, but its duration and spectral characteristics suggest a possible misclassification. We present a detailed analysis of GRB 060912A, examining its observational properties and comparing them to those of both long and short GRBs. This demonstrates the risk inidentifying bright, nearby galaxies as the hosts of given GRBs without furthersupporting evidence. We discuss the implications of this possibility and its ramifications for our understanding of GRBs and their progenitors.

text: The observed multiple populations in Omega Centauri, the most massive Galactic globular cluster, have been attributed to different helium abundances. Polluted models are consistent with observedmerging of the main sequences as opposed to our models of helium rich stars.Using the (B-R)/(B+V+R) statistic, we find that the high helium bMS starsrequire an age difference compared to the rMS stars that is too great, whereasthe pollution scenario stars have no such conflict for inferred Omega Centaurimass losses. We simulate the maximum-AGB models, maximizing the impact of AGB stars, and compare the enrichment history of helium, metals, carbon, and nitrogen to the observed values. Our results show that the maximum-AGB models fail to reproduce the large values of helium and helium enrichment parameter, and the C and N contents of the blue population. We conclude that the AGB scenario with the canonical stellar evolution theory cannot explain the observational constraints, calling for alternative processes.

text: In this paper, we investigate the phenomenon of cascading behavior in large blog graphs. We propose a novel method for identifying and analyzing cascades in blog networks, which allows us to study the spread of information and influence through blog posts and comments. Our approach is based on the idea of temporal precursors and laggards, which we use to quantify the relationship between blogs in terms of their posting behavior. Our analysis also shedslight on how rumors, viruses, and ideas propagate over social and computernetworks. We then use this score to estimate the temporal relationships between blogs and identify cascades of influence. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our method on a real-world dataset of French political blogs, and show that it can be used to identify influential bloggers and understand the dynamics of topic participation on the network. Our results provide valuable insights into the nature of information diffusion in blog networks, and have important implications for the design of search engine ranking algorithms and other applications.

text: Diffusion processes on small-world networks with distance-dependent random links are studied in this paper. The authors first introduce a new method to generate small-world networks with tunable distance-dependent random links. Using this method, they investigate the effects of distance-dependent random links on the diffusion processes in small-world networks. The asymptotic analytic results are alsoconfirmed numerically by employing exact numerical diagonalization of thenetwork Laplacian. The authors also explore the effects of network topology, link weight distribution, and random link density on the diffusion processes. They show that the diffusion processes are strongly influenced by the correlation between link weight and distance, and that the optimal diffusion path can be controlled by tuning the distance-dependent random links. The results have important implications for understanding diffusion processes in complex networks and could be useful in developing new strategies for controlling and optimizing diffusion processes in real-world systems.

text: In this article, we present the Corbino experimental set-up for Cooper pair mass spectroscopy and determine the mobility in the normal phase. The Corbino geometry is a versatile platform for studying the transport properties of superconductors, and we utilize it to measure the coefficient of kinetic friction and the mobility of Cooper pairs in the normal state. By applying a magnetic field perpendicular to the plane of the Corbino disk, we can modify the chemical potential and observe the changes in the Cooper pair mass. In the normal phase 2f gives logarithmicderivative of the density of states (DOS) with respect of Fermi energy.Applying a gate voltage in the same structure gives the mobility of the normalphase. Our findings have important implications for the understanding of the behavior of Cooper pairs in superconductors and their potential applications in electronic devices. The Corbino experimental set-up provides a powerful tool for studying the properties of Cooper pairs and their interaction with the crystal lattice, and our results demonstrate the potential of this technique for advancing our understanding of superconductivity.

text: The aqueous and crystalline forms of L-alanine zwitterion have been investigated using a combination of experimental and computational methods. The structural properties of the aqueous form were studied using NMR spectroscopy, while the crystalline form was characterized using X-ray crystallography. Molecular dynamics simulations were also performed to investigate the dynamic properties of the aqueous form. Overall, our findings stronglysuggest that the generally accepted approach of extending the structuralinformation acquired from crystallographic data to a L-alanine molecule inaqueous solution should be used with caution. In contrast, the crystalline form is much more rigid, with a highly ordered structure. The study provides new insights into the properties of L-alanine zwitterion in different environments, and highlights the importance of considering the effects of solvent and crystal structure on the properties of biological molecules.

text: This paper proposes cooperative transmission protocols that combine multiuser detection and network coding to achieve high spectral efficiency and high diversity order. The proposed protocols are designed to take advantage of the broadcast nature of wireless channels and improve the performance of cooperative transmission systems. The use of multiuser detection allows for the improvement of one user's link to benefit other users, while network coding enables the relay to fully utilize the link between the relay and the destination. The coding gain and high diversity order can beobtained by fully utilizing the link between the relay and the destination. The performance of the proposed scheme is near optimal, with a performance gap of 0.12dB for average BER of 10^-6 and 1.04dB for average BER of 10^-3, compared to two performance upper bounds. The proposed protocols have the potential to significantly improve the performance of future wireless networks.
label: llm

text: In this article, we explore the role of geometry and topology in relativistic cosmology. We begin by discussing the importance of understanding the geometric and topological properties of the universe, particularly in the context of cosmic microwave background (CMB) data. We then examine the use of multipole vectors in decomposing CMB data and analyzing the resulting multipole vector distribution on the sky. In particular, a finite universewith the topology of the Poincar\'e dodecahedral spherical space fitsremarkably well the data and is a good candidate for explaining both the localcurvature of space and the large angle anomalies in the temperature powerspectrum. Finally, we discuss the unique dynamical properties of the Poincare dodecahedral space and its potential implications for our understanding of cosmic topology.

text: This paper argues that the concept of Dark Energy, which is a hypothetical form of energy that is thought to be responsible for the accelerating expansion of the universe, is problematic for astronomy. The authors contend that the idea of Dark Energy is not well-defined and lacks a clear physical interpretation, making it difficult to test or validate through observational data. They also suggest that the introduction of Dark Energy has led to a proliferation of arbitrary and non-parsimonious models in cosmology, which has hindered the development of a coherent and predictive theory of the universe. Dark Energy is undeniably an interesting problem to attack throughastronomical observation, but it is one of many and not necessarily the onewhere significant progress is most likely to follow a major investment ofresources. They conclude that the concept of Dark Energy is a misleading and unhelpful construct that should be re-evaluated in light of new observational and theoretical developments.
label: llm

text: In this article, we present a new fundamental-measure density functional for the fluid of aligned hard hexagons. This functional is based on Rosenfeld's fundamental measure theory and provides a promising route to map out the full phase diagram of the system. We derive an expression for the direct correlation function from the functional and use it to perform a bifurcation analysis. Apart fromstudying the freezing of this system, we discuss the implications of thefunctional structure for new developments of fundamental measure theory. We also predict a metastable nematic-nematic demixing, which is not observed in simulations nor in experiments. The results of the fundamental-measure functional are quantitatively superior to those obtained from the second and third virial approximations. Our findings provide new insights into fundamental measure theory and its application to the study of fluid phases.

text: In this study, we investigate the transverse polarization of Lambda and Lambda-bar hyperons in quasireal photoproduction. Our results provide new insights into the structure of these hyperons and shed light on the underlying mechanisms of their interactions with photons. By analyzing the transverse polarization of the hyperons, we find that their behavior is consistent with the expected helicity-flip amplitude, which is a key indicator of the internal structure of these particles. The dependences of Lambda and Lambda-bar polarizations on thefraction $\zeta$ of the beam's light-cone momentum carried by the hyperon andon the hyperon's transverse momentum $p_T$ were investigated. This study demonstrates the power of quasireal photoproduction as a tool for probing the properties of hyperons and provides a valuable stepping stone for future investigations in this area.

text: This article examines the statistical properties of the points where nodal lines intersect a reference curve. Nodal lines are lines in a Riemannian manifold that are defined by the solutions of a certain differential equation. The intersection points of these lines with a reference curve are of particular interest in various fields, including physics, engineering, and computer science. We apply these statistics in particular tonodal patterns of random waves and of eigenfunctions of chaotic billiards. Our results show that the distribution of intersection points is closely related to the curvature of the reference curve and the properties of the nodal lines. We also demonstrate several applications of our findings, including the analysis of statistical patterns in numerical simulations and the optimization of computational algorithms. Our work provides new insights into the geometry and statistics of nodal lines and their intersections, and has important implications for future research in these areas.

text: This article explores the concept of splitting trees and its relationship to Lévy processes. Splitting trees have been widely studied in the field of mathematics, particularly in the context of geometric functions and their limits. However, the connection between splitting trees and Lévy processes has not been well-established. Our research aims to bridge this gap by demonstrating that the contour of splitting trees can be characterized as a Lévy process.We begin by providing a thorough explanation of splitting trees and their properties. We demonstrate that the contour of a splitting tree can be viewed as a random fractal, which is a subset of the complex plane that exhibits self-similarity. We then introduce the concept of Lévy processes and their characteristics, including their ability to model random motion and the presence of “fat tails” in their distribution.Our main result shows that the contour of a splitting tree can be represented as a Lévy process. We introduce a total order onexistence points, called linear order, and a mapping $\varphi$ from the treeinto the real line which preserves this order. Each element of achronological tree is a (so-called) existence point $(v,\tau)$ of someindividual $v$ (vertex) in a discrete tree, where $\tau$ is a nonnegative realnumber called chronological level (time). They provide a new perspective on the behavior of splitting trees, and highlight the role of Lévy processes in modeling random phenomena. Additionally, our results open up new avenues for research, including the application of Lévy processes to the study of other fractals and random processes.Overall, this article provides a novel contribution to the field of mathematics, and has important implications for our understanding of the behavior of random processes. Its findings have the potential to inspire new lines of inquiry, and to shed light on the fundamental principles that govern the behavior of complex systems.

text: Abstract:NGC3603, a massive young cluster located in the Milky Way galaxy, is exposed to a unique interstellar radiation field (ISRF) that affects the physical conditions and evolution of its embedded stars. Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), abundant in the interstellar medium, play a crucial role in the ISRF by absorbing and re-emitting radiation. This study investigates the relationship between PAH strength and the ISRF around NGC3603, using a combination of observational data and radiation transfer modeling. (2006). Our results suggest that the ISRF around NGC3603 is primarily shaped by the absorption and scattering of light by PAHs, which in turn affects the thermal balance and photochemistry of the surrounding interstellar gas. The observed correlation between PAH strength and ISRF intensity provides valuable insights into the complexity of the interstellar medium and its interaction with radiation. Our findings have important implications for the study of star formation and the evolution of massive clusters.

text: This study examines the flow of autonomous traffic on a single multi-lane street, with a focus on optimizing traffic efficiency and safety. Finally, the article concludes by proposing several strategies for optimizing autonomous traffic flow and improving road safety, including the implementation of advanced driver assistance systems and the integration of autonomous vehicles into existing transportation infrastructure. text: In this article, we examine the quantization of piecewise affine maps on the torus and their ensuing quantum limitations. We then delve into the process of quantization and its application to these maps, brought to light by the challenges and opportunities that arise in the quantum realm. In particular we can construct examples ofergodic maps which have singular ergodic measures as quantum limits, andexamples of non-ergodic maps where arbitrary convex combinations of absolutelycontinuous ergodic measures can occur as quantum limits. Finally, we conclude with a deliberation of the consequences of our discoveries and their potential applications in areas such as quantum computing and chaos theory.

text: In this article, we investigate the connection between bubbling AdS spacetimes and droplet descriptions of BPS geometries in IIB supergravity. First, we review the concept of bubbling AdS spacetimes and their importance in the AdS/CFT correspondence. Next, we introduce the notion of droplet descriptions of BPS geometries and explore their relationship to bubbling AdS spacetimes.Through various examples, we demonstrate how droplet descriptions encode information about the geometry and topology of BPS boundaries in IIB supergravity. The AdS_5 x S^5 ground state corresponds to excising the interior of anS^5, while the 1/8 BPS excitations correspond to deformations (includingtopology change) of the S^5 and/or the excision of additional droplets from thebase. We also discuss the implications for our understanding of the AdS/CFT correspondence and the nature of black holes in String theory. Finally, we outline future research directions, including the study of droplet descriptions in other contexts and their relationship to other areas of mathematics and physics.Our work highlights the power of droplet descriptions as a tool for understanding BPS boundaries, providing a fresh perspective on the relationship between bubbling AdS spacetimes and BPS geometries in IIB supergravity.

text: In this article, we investigate the complexity of Villamayor's algorithm in the non exceptional monomial case, a widely used method for computing the primary decomposition of a monomial ideal in a polynomial ring. While the algorithm's complexity has been well-studied in the exceptional monomial case, its complexity in the non exceptional monomial case has received less attention.Our study presents a detailed analysis of the algorithm's complexity in the non exceptional monomial case, taking into account factors such as the number of variables, the degree of the ideal, and the coefficient matrix. Our findings reveal that the algorithm's complexity can vary significantly depending on these factors, and can be quite high in some cases.We also compare the complexity of Villamayor's algorithm with that of other algorithms for computing the primary decomposition of monomial ideals, including the Buchberger-Mölter algorithm and the Hibi-Matsumura algorithm. Computation of examples has been helpful in both cases to study the behaviourof the resolution invariant. We also discuss potential avenues for future research on improving the efficiency of Villamayor's algorithm in the non exceptional monomial case.In conclusion, our research contributes to a deeper understanding of the complexity of Villamayor's algorithm and its limitations in the non exceptional monomial case, providing valuable insights for practitioners and researchers working in computational commutative algebra.

text: This study presents a photometric analysis of the intermediate-age star cluster BS 90, located in the star-forming region NGC 346 within the Small Magellanic Cloud (SMC). Utilizing Hubble Space Telescope Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) observations, we investigated the properties of BS 90 and its surrounding environment. The high-resolution imaging capabilities of the ACS allowed us to examine the cluster's structure and color properties in detail. We found that BS 90 has an age of approximately 200 million years, placing it in the intermediate-age range between young and old clusters. The cluster's color-magnitude diagram exhibits a clear red giant branch, indicating significant evolution since its formation. We identified a number of asymptotic giant branch (AGB) stars, likely precursors of planetary nebulae. The luminosity functionis constructed and the present-day mass function of BS 90 has been obtainedusing the mass-luminosity relation, derived from the isochrone models. Isochrone fits on theCMD of the cluster results in an age of about 4.5 Gyr. This study provides valuable insights into the star formation history of the SMC and the evolution of intermediate-age clusters. The results can inform future research on the formation and evolution of star clusters in external galaxies.

text: In this study, we investigate the properties of quasars at redshift z~6 using millimeter and radio observations. Our sample consists of 12 quasars selected from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) and followed up with the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) and the Very Large Array (VLA). We detected millimeter and radio emission from all 12 quasars, with luminosities spanning 10^26 to 10^28 W Hz^(-1). These data are consistent with,although do not set strong constraints on, a decreasing radio-loud quasarfraction with increasing redshift. By interpreting these observations within the context of quasar evolution, we find that the flat-spectrum sources are likely young, recently triggered quasars, while the steep-spectrum sources are older, more evolved quasars. Our results offer fresh insights into the early stages of quasar evolution and emphasize the significance of multi-wavelength observations in understanding the growth and development of supermassive black holes.
